TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to sessional order, I give notice that it is my intention, on behalf of Senator Missen, the former Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, at discovery of formal business on the next day of sitting, to withdraw Business of the Senate, Notice of Motion No. 1, standing in his name for that day, relating to the disallowance of the Nature Conservation Ordinance 1980, as contained in Australian Capital Territory Ordinance No. 20 of 1980, and made under the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910.

—Before Question Time commences may I take the opportunity, on behalf of the Opposition, to express my concurrence with the remarks made by Senator Carrick about our colleague, Senator Knight. He is a man much respected on the Opposition side of the Senate.

—I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate whether it is correct, as reported in the Press, that the Government Information Unit is to be expanded with the addition of another two journalists and up to seven secretarial staff. How many people are currently employed by this Unit? Where are they located? What are their salaries and allowances? How many more staff is it the Government's intention to engage?

—The Government Information Unit has a central staff of four in Canberra and a Federal information director in each State capital. The Unit provides a service to Ministers who do not have Press secretaries. The Government has decided to enhance the effectiveness of the Unit through a modest increase in staff numbers. An additional media officer and two support staff are being appointed to the central office, and each Federal information director is to have a support staff member. Provision is also made for the appointment of a Federal information director in Darwin. The total expenditure on the Unit in 1979-80 was $279,018. It is estimated that expenditure in 1980-81 will be $340,000. This is a quite modest amount when compared with the expenditure by State governments on public relations activities. For instance-I say this with the knowledge of the huge expenditure made by the Whitlam Government in this regard-the New South Wales Government spends upwards of $1m on its public relations machinery and information services. Similar amounts are spent in Victoria and Queensland. The Government has a responsibility to ensure that its policies, programs and activities are effectively communicated. The Government Information Unit performs this role at a minimum cost to the taxpayer.
—I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. Will the Government give serious consideration to the indexation of all unemployment benefits? If not, why not?

—Most honourable senators will be aware that some unemployment benefits are indexed and some are not. Those benefits which are not are the single unemployment benefit and unemployment benefit for those under the age of 18 years. The rates of payment to such beneficiaries are a matter which is considered by the Government on a year to year basis, and adjustments were made to the payments to single unemployed beneficiaries last year. This matter will be considered again in the Budget context, and I will undertake to consider the point raised by the honourable senator in his question in that context.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister for National Development and Energy, concerns the interdepartmental committee which is preparing a new legislative base for the development of an Australian nuclear industry. Is the Minister aware that the Australian States, particularly the Premiers, are currently falling over each other to sell off our coal reserves cheaply to multinational aluminium companies? Does he agree that it is utterly inept economic management to denude ourselves of coal in this way and then to assert that we have to have nuclear power plants because we are short of energy resources? Will the Minister consider setting up a Federal interdepartmental committee into solar energy, tidal energy and other forms of energy which will not produce toxic wastes lasting hundreds of thousands of years? Has he noted the committee's suggestion that 'another issue requiring further attention is provision for liability and compensation for nuclear damage'? Why is the committee contemplating such a hideous event? Has the Minister any conception of or information on what the term 'nuclear damage' entails for Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the basis of Senator Chipp's question flows from a misunderstanding of the work of the interdepartmental committee. It is not normal for me to comment upon something that appears in the Press as an apparent leak because, along with many other senators, I hold in contempt those who leak documents. Having said that, I am happy to report that, as is known, the Prime Minister set up an interdepartmental committee basically to look at the whole question of the recasting of the Atomic Energy Act. The Atomic Energy Act had been, in the past, basically a defence Act. A lot of nuclear requirements these days are non-defence. For example, in industry, medicine, science and nuclear physics radioactive isotopes are a major subject. So there is a need to recast the whole of the Act. The IDC has been working on that. The terms of reference for a general review of the Atomic Energy Act were announced and tabled in Parliament by the Deputy Prime Minister on 21 August last year. These state that the review would take account of, amongst other things, the requirements for the regulation, licensing and development of a nuclear industry in Australia, but in no way do they foreshadow that one is likely in the near or immediate future.

ANSWER.PARA: A report has been prepared by officials and it will be considered by the Government in due course. This, of course, will be of major importance. As to the first part of Senator Chipp's question, I am aware that there is an important discussion going on at this moment as to the use of the various resources of this country-coal, bauxite, alumina, aluminium-and their relative uses so as to get the maximum or optimum benefit for the Australian community. I think a Senate committee is doing a valuable service in studying the aluminium industry. At this moment there is a dialogue as to whether the cost of coal in producing electricity for aluminium production is a real cost. I think that dialogue is a healthy one in the public interest.

There is no suggestion that I know of at this moment that a nuclear power plant be established in Australia. The Government and I are greatly concerned that all our resources, particularly coal, shall be used to their best advantage. We have a responsibility to export because of the shortage of energy overseas. We have to balance exports, power generation, coal liquefaction and the employment of Australians. A much more important consideration overriding those factors is the preservation of reserves for the generations ahead. These considerations raise important questions.

I have been asked whether we will establish an interdepartmental committee on solar or tidal energy. I only wish that the present knowledge on solar energy were sufficient for us to probe further at this immediate time to develop it further. My estimate is that by the year 2000-that is about 20 years down the track-about 8 per cent of Australian energy will be provided by the renewable source of solar energy. If it is possible to increase that percentage we will try to do that, but at this moment there are great barriers in scientific knowledge. The best thing to do now is to apply significant research. We are doing so. Many attempts to use tidal energy are being made in the world. We have some disabilities in Australia, even though we have high tides in such places as Broome and Darwin. We are looking at that matter.

Senator Chipp asked about possible nuclear damage. I acknowledge that any abuse or misuse of nuclear energy would cause harm. I have to say that one of the great worries current throughout the world today is that the contemplated volume of coal used for world-wide thermal use could cause-not only by pollution but also by altering the atmosphere-all sorts of great threats to health; indeed, threats to health at least parallel to those of nuclear energy. We must not simply look at any one situation. That is not to say that we are not conscious of the situation. We in Australia have the highest standards of preservation in supervision of nuclear activities. We will take the same steps with the use of coal. Throughout the world there needs to be a balance in coal for export, power generation and liquefaction. But, above everything else, there must be a preservation for the future. Within that context we will need to get an energy balance. If, in the longer term future nuclear energy is considered to be of use in Australia, I am utterly sure that it will be utilised only with the maximum safeguards that are known to science.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Attorney-General to a letter by Professor Colin Howard, Dean of the Faculty of Law at Melbourne University, which appeared in the Age on 19 February 1981. It relates to copyright laws within Australia. Will the Attorney-General comment on Professor Howard's claim that under the new copyright provisions no parts of Acts, except those permitted by law, can be reproduced without the permission of the Commonwealth? Is the Attorney-General aware of the problems which enforcement of this restriction will cause to those people who may, for very many reasons, wish to reproduce all or part of an Act of the Parliament? Does the Attorney-General agree with Professor Howard's statement that 'in any democracy worth the name, the law of the land ought to be freely available to everyone to read and to copy if they wish'? If so, will consideration be given by the Government to changing the present law of copyright to ensure that access of the citizen to the law is maintained?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention was drawn to the letter from Professor Howard to which Senator Missen referred. I think the copyright Acts contain some qualifications to the concerns that the professor expressed. Of course, one can use the Acts for certain purposes. I think these should be taken into account in assessing the concern which Professor Howard expressed. I refer now to the general question of reproduction of Acts of Parliament. Of course, it has always been assumed by government that it has a responsibility to make known, by publishing, accurate accounts of the laws that are passed. Indeed, that is why we produce the annual volumes of Acts and why we are now proceeding to keep reprints going in the new way which was the subject of a statement by me in the Senate some time ago.

ANSWER.PARA: In addition, arrangements have been made with certain publishers to publish Acts of Parliament which are in particular demand. For instance, CCH Australia Ltd's publications have provided a very useful service. By and large the publishers are more interested in doing work of that kind in respect of Acts for which there is a great deal of demand, although some representations have been made to me by Butterworths Pty Ltd to publish Acts on a wider scale. However, as far as I am aware, not a great many people are interested in publishing Acts of Parliament broadly. Where there is a special interest in specific Acts we have made arrangements with those interested publishers to permit the publication of such Acts. I believe that the needs of the public are being pretty well served by the present methods of publication.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Social Security, arises out of the decision of the Government to allow invalid pension applicants to appeal to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal against decisions of the Department-particularly in New South Wales. When will the Government establish procedures to be used by the Social Security Appeals Tribunal in New South Wales? When will it appoint new members so that the Tribunal can deal with the large backlog of cases and when, in particular, will medical members be appointed to the new Tribunal? Will these medical members be Commonwealth medical officers who may have been responsible for the decisions being appealed against?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In most States now medical members have been appointed to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. I think the one exception to that is Queensland, although there has been one temporary appointment only in New South Wales. The New South Wales appointment is the only one, as far as I am aware, where there is any contact between the person appointed and a career that previously involved this area. A doctor who has accepted appointment on a temporary basis in New South Wales was originally employed in the Department of Health. That appointment is meant to be only a temporary arrangement and other doctors are currently being approached to take up positions on the Social Security Appeals Tribunal in New South Wales.

ANSWER.PARA: This process has taken longer than I would have wished but I hope that within a week or two a full complement of appeals tribunals will be operating in each State and that the backlog will be quickly reduced. I have directed my Department to ensure that no person suffers because of the delay. I have asked my Department to administer the benefit system accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister for Social Security and is also about unemployment relief and about the taxpayer who has to pay for it. I ask: Did the Minister see the television film segment which depicted the Broken Hill strikers filling in applications for unemployment relief for their wives? Does the payment of unemployment relief to wives of striking workers in this manner mean in effect that the taxpayers of Australia are financing the strike at Broken Hill? Does the Government consider that it is right and proper that Australian taxpayers should finance this or any other strike in Australia? What is the Government's policy on this question?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter which is raised by the honourable senator is covered by statute, in particular by section 107 of the Social Services Act. That matter is in my mind because it was raised with me last week by another honourable senator who was querying the same point.

ANSWER.PARA: The position, as I understand it, is that where industrial action is taken that section applies and unemployment benefit is not payable to the person whose unemployment is due to industrial action by him or her or by members of a union of which he or she is a member. The spouses of persons involved in industrial disputes may qualify for unemployment benefit if they are able to meet the normal conditions. That means, of course, that they have to satisfy the work test, be available for employment and so on.

Similarly, spouses may qualify for special benefit where hardship is shown to have occurred. It may well be that the spouse and children of a striking worker may suffer hardship which is not their fault, and it would not be the wish of the Government or the community that those people be left without food or shelter. In any event, in those cases, payment is made to the spouse, where the spouse is entitled to benefit, at the single rate plus the additional benefit for children.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs: Why has the Government not tabled the Program Effectiveness Review report called for by the Prime Minister in December 1979 to draw together information on the broad range of Government programs which directly or indirectly aim to improve the health and lifestyle of Aborigines and clarify the directions of Government policy? When will the report be tabled?

—The document to which the honourable senator referred was prepared by Government as an internal working document for advice to Government. It is not intended at this stage that it should be made public. There are other reports, notably the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs report on Aboriginal health, to which a response is necessary. When a response is made reference will be made in it to the several reports on Aboriginal health and it will include some reference to the PER outcomes.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. It relates to the payment of pensions overseas, pensions which are paid by the Australian taxpayer. In view of the difficulty in deciding whether pensions paid overseas should continue to be paid, and remembering that it is difficult to extract tax from pensions sent overseas if the recipient happens to be working and therefore is earning extra money on which in Australia that person would have to pay tax, will the Minister and the Government examine the whole matter of payment of pensions overseas and the reciprocity of pensions? Does the Minister recognise that most Australians feel that pensions paid by the Australian Government with taxpayers' money should be spent in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a fact that many pensions payable in Australia are also payable overseas if the person who qualifies for the pension in Australia subsequently leaves this country. The question of reciprocal pension rights is one of considerable complexity. I think most honourable senators would be aware that there have been some discussions between representatives of the Australian Government and representatives of governments in countries which have large migrant populations in Australia. The matter is currently receiving consideration within the Government. I anticipate that there will be further discussions with the interested countries during this calendar year.

ANSWER.PARA: I agree with the honourable senator that the payment of pensions overseas gives rise to some difficulties which are not experienced when pensions are payable within Australia. For that reason, in both London and Geneva we have maintained officers who are concerned in the payment of social security benefits. Indeed, there is a constant process of checking to ensure that the appropriate pensions are being paid to the appropriate people. I will bear in mind the suggestions which are implicit in the honourable senator's question in the examination of the whole question of reciprocal rights during the current year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for National Development and Energy whether he is aware that a fairly large amount of radioactive waste was discovered in a consignment of scrap metal which was forwarded from Western Australia to Singapore about two years ago. Can the Minister inform the Parliament what the Australian Government intends to do about the waste? Is it a fact that Singapore has disclaimed responsibility for disposal of the material? If the Government brings the radioactive material back to Australia, how will it be transported, and what methods of disposal will be used?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Several years ago some scrap metal, which I think had derived from the Western Mining Corporation, was exported by Simsmetal Pty Ltd to Singapore. Shortly after its arrival the Director of Health in Western Australia informed his opposite number in Singapore that it was felt that a measuring gauge which contained radioactive material may have been inadvertently included in the scrap metal and therefore there may be some radioactive risk. In fact, it emerged that that was so. The radioactive material, which included scrap metal which had also been contaminated, was made safe and has been kept safe. Discussions have occurred between the commercial elements in Singapore and the commercial elements in Australia and subsequently at government level.

ANSWER.PARA: I have confirmed that, should the material be transported, its degree of radioactivity is such that it can be made perfectly safe for transport. I have been advised by experts on this matter that that can be done. At the moment discussions are taking place at the Western Australian Government level and with the industry concerned as to the handling of the material. If there is to be any movement at all of the material, the honourable senator can be assured that the Commonwealth Government and I, as the Minister responsible for atomic safeguards, will insist upon the strictest possible observance of safeguards so that there will be no threat whatsoever to health. The material is not highly radioactive in the ordinary sense but that does not limit responsibility for it. As to disposal, I understand that a number of ways are under consideration. My understanding is that it is quite possible readily to dispose of it so that in both the long term and the short term there will be no risk to health. I will be watching every step of the journey to see that there is no threat.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I take it from what the Minister has said that he is now disclaiming responsibility for the material in the same way as the Government of Singapore has disclaimed responsibility. Who is going to guard the material? Why is it to be allowed to stay in Singapore when in fact it is the Australian Government's responsibility?

—If Senator Keeffe wants to take it that I said that, he is entitled to do so, but I did not. I said that in all movements of the material the Commonwealth Government would accept responsibility for its safeguarding. My understanding is that the Singapore Government desires it to be brought back to Australia. That and the method of transport and disposal are under consideration at this moment by the Western Australian Government and the industry concerned. I repeat that I have sought and obtained advice that it can be transported readily, causing no harm at all to anyone. Otherwise it would not be moved. I have sought and obtained advice that there are a number of ways of effecting its disposal. The honourable senator will realise that, whether for medical or industrial reasons, radioactive material is used every day in Australia and that there is radioactive waste when use of those materials ceases. Australia has a continuing and long term experience in the disposal of industrial materials and it will apply that experience.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, concerns a need to have close liaison between the officers of the Community Youth Support Scheme and the Commonwealth Employment Service to improve prospects for jobs for unemployed youth. Will the Minister relieve the frustrations of CYSS officers and enable them to assist unemployed youth by allowing these officers to obtain the names and addresses of unemployed youth in their regions? The only information currently available to them from CES offices is the total number of unemployed. Further, will country unemployed be given the facility of phoning CES offices to inquire about job vacancies rather than having to be involved in costly travel to check available jobs listed in metropolitan CES offices?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I can make some response to this question but I may need to seek some information. I am advised by the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs that in the interests of clients of the Department-job seekers and employers-the Commonwealth Employment Service must observe a strict policy of confidentiality in regard to all registrations. Throughout Australia there are approximately 160 Commonwealth Employment Service agencies as well as 237 full time officers to cater for the needs of job seekers. In isolated areas every effort is made to find suitable employment in other areas for the unemployed. There is a system whereby a local agency can circulate to appropriate town or city Commonwealth Employment Service offices details of an unemployed person and the type of work he or she is seeking. The agency is then advised in due course of any suitable vacancies which are available.

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised also that unemployed people in isolated areas may also be assisted under the Commonwealth's Fares and Assistance Scheme. Details of these programs can be made available on request. Other services also exist, including regular visits by vocational officers of the Commonwealth Employment Service to assist job seekers to find suitable employment. In addition to this, I think it ought to be said that the Commonwealth Employment Service has, as one of its fundamental objectives, the matching of people who are seeking employment and job vacancies of which it is aware. I believe improvements in service have resulted from some measures that have been undertaken. However, I will refer Senator Watson's question to the Minister to see whether he wishes to make any further response on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister for Social Security. My question is prompted by the case of a 15-year-old girl who, because of exceptional circumstances, applied for special benefit. She subsequently was granted a special benefit of $10 a week. Is special benefit to those aged under 16 limited to $10 a week? If so, for how long has this been the case?
—I am not sure of the answer to that question. I will check on it and let the honourable senator have an early reply.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which concerns the Qantas Airways Ltd strike, is ad- dressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I draw to the Minister's attention the editorial in today's Australian which I believe expresses the overwhelming view of the Australian people. The editorial states:

QUESTION.PARA: All Australians who share the ownership of our once proud international airline are closely watching moves in the Prime Minister's carefully prepared plan to get Qantas back in the air . . .

We believe that Australians are united as seldom before on the Qantas issue and fed up to the extreme with the public-bashing tactics of the unions . . . Mr Fraser can be sure of public support for any stern steps he is forced to take.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to the relevant Standing Order that refers to an honourable senator giving information. It is quite obvious that Senator Teague, in these circumstances--
—It is because of the militant-

—The Deputy President will rule whether there is a point of order. Senator Teague is obviously taking this opportunity to make a second reading speech and to give information to the Senate. I suggest that you refer him to the correct Standing Order.
—There is no point of order.
—The editorial concluded:

QUESTION.PARA: Mr Fraser can be sure of public support for any stern steps he is forced to take.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The question must be relevant to the Minister's portfolio. It must be a question from an honourable senator. We were hearing an honourable senator without the ability to formulate a question. All he can do is read out an editorial from the Australian for the purpose of making himself look wise. If we have to put up with idiots like this, I do not think it is fair that we have to do so at Question Time. I think you should rule him out of order.
—Order! There is no point of order. Senator Teague, you will come to the end of your question.
—I ask the honourable senator to withdraw his remarks which related to my apparent idiocy.
—Senator Cavanagh, you have been asked to withdraw that remark.
—I do. I take it that we do have to put up with idiots like that.
—Order! You will withdraw unreservedly.
—I have withdrawn it. We have to put up with it.
—You will withdraw unreservedly.
—Yes.
—I ask: Has the Government given the firmest guarantees of support to Qantas management?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has received an enormous volume of congratulatory messages from the community at large relating particularly to its action of using Royal Australian Air Force aircraft to relieve the great suffering of Australian and New Zealand people on each side of the Tasman. The Government has been overwhelmed with responses from people who have shown that they oppose the action of the unionists in bringing on the strike and who want the Government and Qantas Airways Ltd to stand firm. Let me make it perfectly clear that the Qantas management intends to preserve the right to use staff labour in essential services where necessary to keep the airline flying. The Government gives unqualified support to that principle. That principle will be observed.

ANSWER.PARA: I believe the meeting of unionists this afternoon showed an almost equal division of people. I can only hope that good sense will prevail and that what is a proud and excellent airline by world standards will not be damaged by the reckless action of those who seek militant union power. I make an appeal for good sense to prevail and for the unionists to go back to work. They can talk when they are back at work and we will keep the airline flying and providing an excellent service to the people of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —In terms of the good sense mentioned by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, I ask him whether his attention has been drawn to the very reasonable statement by Mr Hawke yesterday.
—Ha, ha!

—Is that showing a reasonable attitude? Last night Bob Hawke, without criticism of the Government, of the airline or of the unionists, suggested three new procedures which have not been fully considered. Some of the disputes procedures have been considered, but Mr Hawke proposed three procedures which might well form a new basis for discussion. Has the Minister had an opportunity to look at them? If he has, will he give us his opinion of them? If he has not, will he discuss with his colleague the Minister for Industrial Relations whether those suggestions by Mr Hawke might be the basis for discussion between the parties in the same sense of conciliation as that displayed in the closing words of the Minister's previous answer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government would examine on their merits suggestions from anyone who put them forward. In that spirit we have in fact examined the suggestions made by Mr Hawke. Of course, Mr Hawke's suggestions contain a fundamental difficulty in terms of the principle I outlined. One of Mr Hawke's suggestions is that Qantas must accept bans applied by a union or unions regardless of the nature of such bans, their duration or their impact on the operations of the company. In other words, the bans could be applied to individual aircraft or to individual pieces of equipment. They could be applied by one or more unions. That would, in fact, be a device that could bring the airline to a halt by indirect means.

ANSWER.PARA: In any case, as I understand it, Mr Hawke's thesis envisaged permitting the use of staff labour when there were wild-cat strikes but not when there were not wild-cat strikes. The fact is that, if it is right to keep an airline going by using staff labour in wild-cat strikes, it is right to keep an airline going at any time. I guess there would be a great deal of contention as to what is a wild-cat strike and what is an ordinary strike; but, fundamentally, no government and certainly no airline could agree that it would accept the right of a union, in terms of a settlement, to impose bans, in fact to blackban aircraft or equipment. On that basis, there is really nothing new in what Mr Hawke has said, and it is not practicable within the principles.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister to consider whether, in view of a stalemate in the dispute, at least the parties concerned might give consideration to starting at the point suggested by Mr Hawke, even in light of the Minister's point of view. While some of the proposals may appear difficult in the first stage because they are new proposals, they could well be the start of discussions which could be fruitful. In that sense, would the Minister, together with his colleague, give consideration to the possibilities of the matter?

—I am advised that there is nothing at all new in the proposal. The elements of the proposal have been put forward and considered in the past. My advice is quite clearly that neither Qantas nor the Government could start on the basis of an acceptance of the right of unions to impose bans because bans could be such that they could be so imposed as to render it impossible for the airline to fly. Under those circumstances, the conditions could be intolerable.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. As the restructuring of the national highway in Tasmania is nearing completion, will the Minister consider transposing a large map of Tasmania over the map of the northern island of Australia when the national highway sign is erected for the new highway? This will enable travellers of the Tasmanian highway to see clearly the full route of these highways in my State. Mr Deputy President, it is impossible to see the route on the present inadequately signposted map.

—Senator Walters is well known for bringing before the Parliament and the Government the affairs and the importance of the State of Tasmania. She has done so again on this occasion. This matter appears to have some merit. However, there seems to be some cost associated with it, which may or may not be relevant to the question. However, I will refer the matter to my colleague and obtain an early reply for the honourable senator.

—My question is also directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. Does he join the Minister for Transport in challenging the veracity of the three members of the public inquiry into domestic air fares-Mr Holcroft, Dr Bell and Professor Hogan? Does he also accept the statement that the members of the inquiry were not warned that the inquiry was to be curtailed and that the report was to be produced by 31 January? If he does not accept the statement by the three members of the inquiry, can he explain why no public hearings were held in Victoria, South Australia or Queensland and why no evidence was taken from the major airlines or from the Department of Transport? Finally, does the Minister agree with the implications of public statements by the Minister for Transport that he regards the members of the inquiry as incompetent?

—In view of the nature of the many parts of the question which Senator Button has raised and, indeed, the detail which he seeks, I will refer the matter to the Minister for Transport and obtain an early reply.

—Mr Deputy President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. In view of the fact that the Minister declines to answer because my question is too detailed for him, I ask him again: Does he accept the statement that the members of the Holcroft inquiry were not warned that the inquiry was to be curtailed and that the report was to be produced by 31 January?
—I am advised by the Minister that the Government gave consideration to--
—'I am advised'-the lie is out.
—I would have thought, as Senator Button was seeking information, he would be interested in the reply and the information that I have.
—I am.

—Apparently your colleague is not so inclined. I will go on though to make one or two remarks concerning this matter. I am advised by the Minister that the Government gave consideration to Mr Holcroft's formal request on 14 November and resolved to ask the Committee to report by 31 January 1981. There were subsequent matters in relation to that, but that is all the information that I have at my disposal at the moment.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is the Australian Government monitoring the assaults on human rights under way in Iran at present, particularly those directed against members of the Baha'i community? What action has Australia taken to bring these violations to the attention of the United Nations and other appropriate bodies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is deeply concerned about evidence of violations of human rights in Iran. The Baha'is, for instance, are denied any constitutional rights as a religious minority and have suffered gross discrimination including imprisonment and execution without fair trial, destruction of property and desecration of their holy places. It has become clear that the Baha'i faith is under systematic attack. This pattern of persecution runs counter to the Islamic ideals espoused by the Iranian Revolution and reflects a derogation from civilised standards which is also apparent, though on a lesser scale, in the Iranian authorities' treatment of the constitutionally recognised Christian, Jewish and Zoroastrian minorities.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has been closely monitoring the situation and has used available opportunities to protest in the strongest terms against these human rights violations. The Iranian Charge d'Affaires has been asked several times to convey the Government's concern to the Iranian Government. We are glad that negotiations for the release of three imprisoned Anglicans are proceeding but remain concerned at the treatment of churches in Iran.

TALK.START.PARA: —The three imprisoned Anglicans have already been released.

—Thank you for that information. Australia is actively engaged at present in discussions in Geneva with like-minded members of the Commission on Human Rights to determine ways in which the meeting of the Commission might help to improve the position of religious minorities in Iran.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. Why has the Government decided not to give short term assistance to the Australian pig industry with respect to the import of canned hams? Is it a fact that the sources of imports, namely Yugoslavia and Romania, enjoy developing country preferences? Is it a fact that these countries are dumping canned ham on the Australian market? Have Australian firms stated that they will import from overseas affiliates if no protection is given? Does the Minister realise that the Government's inaction could result in drastic income losses for thousands of Australian pig farmers? Is the Government confident that the import of hams from countries with foot and mouth disease does not place the Australian livestock industry at risk?
—I will seek from the Minister for Primary Industry a reply to that series of questions.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PUBLIC TELEPHONE FACILITIES AT POST OFFICES

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister representing the Minister for Communications know or could he ascertain whether the public is being denied additional public telephone facilities at some official post offices because of Australia Post's attitude in charging Telecom Australia what are alleged to be exorbitant rentals for the space required?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some information in relation to this question. I am advised that the location of telephone facilities at official post offices is covered by an agreement between Australia Post and Telecom Australia. The rental charged for space for such facilities has remained unchanged for the past five-year period to 30 June 1980. The agreement is currently being renegotiated and the matter of an increase in charges is the subject of discussions between both commissions.

ANSWER.PARA: A flat charge has applied throughout Australia for the location of telephones at official post offices and the charge has consisted of several components including rental of space, electricity consumption and lamp maintenance. Australia Post considers that any proposed increase in the charge would not be exorbitant but would reflect present market rental values. Telecom does not intend that the public should be denied additional telephone facilities.

When considering particular sites, however, Telecom believes that any proposed increases in the basic charge must be viewed against the costs, visibility and other aspects of alternative sites. Should the honourable senator have any particular location or locations in mind, Telecom would be pleased to investigate the matter further.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, concerns the discrimination which this Government practices against Tasmanian babies and mothers. Can the Minister tell me why mothers of babies born in Tasmania receive medical benefits from the Federal Government of only $128, whereas babies born in New South Wales attract a Government subsidy of $195? In order to explain the $67 differential maybe the Minister, who comes from New South Wales, could take the Senate into his confidence and tell us why he believes that babies born in New South Wales are of such superior quality as to warrant such a differential? Alternatively, does the Minister consider that babies born in Tasmania are of some inferior quality?

—To answer the last part of the question first, I can only point out to the honourable senator that babies born in New South Wales often grow up to be senators for Tasmania. There are at least two of them in this place at present. I take it that the honourable senator is referring to medical benefit rebates payable to people for obstetrical services. My understanding is that this is something that emerged over the years when medical rebates were obtained on different costings which were attributed to the doctors operating in each State. I had thought there had been some movement over the last few years towards uniform benefit rebates. If there is a remaining problem I will get some more detailed information for the honourable senator.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. It relates to the premature and tragic death last year of Queensland-born Major- General John Williamson, who served so successfully as commander of the last major tri-Service and international exercise, Kangaroo III, at Shoalwater Bay in central Queensland. He was a man whose ability and professional reputation were such that writers in their obituaries referred to him as a future Chief of Defence Force Staff had he lived. Will the Department of Defence honour the memory of this soldier by naming the large airfield which has just been built at the north end of the Shoalwater Bay training area Williamson Field, as amongst Service personnel and civilians who live in the central Queensland area and who knew the late General, there is very strong support for this move?

—I am afraid that I cannot provide very much information for Senator MacGibbon. He obviously has made an interesting and valuable suggestion. I will certainly pass it to the Minister for Defence and ask him to consider it.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Senator Walsh proceeding to address a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate-

Senator Carrick-Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to the remarks of the honourable senator, which are objectionable under Standing Orders. I ask that you have them withdrawn and the question ruled out of order.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is ruled out of order. The honourable senator cannot reflect on a member of the other House. He mentioned the name of Mr Sinclair.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Walsh-Mr Deputy President, I move dissent from your ruling on the grounds that an almost identical question was asked and accepted on 5 December last year.
Senator Carrick-Before any other procedural matters take place I ask that Senator Walsh be asked to withdraw the remarks he made as they are objectionable.

Senator Button-Mr Deputy President, you now find yourself in the position of Senator Carrick's taking a point of order, of your ruling on it with great alacrity if I might say so, and Senator Walsh's then dissenting from your ruling. The Minister now seeks to get in a further point which would obviate the ruling which you have already made. You should act on the matter which is now before you, namely, Senator Walsh's dissent from your ruling.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I did ask Senator Walsh to withdraw his remarks in respect of Mr Sinclair. I think that should be done first. Once that has been dealt with we will deal with Senator Walsh's motion of dissent from the Deputy President's ruling. Senator Walsh, I ask you to withdraw your remarks first.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Walsh-The sequence of events was not that you asked me to withdraw my remarks first. Senator Carrick asked you to rule the question out of order, which you did. I submit that the matter now before the Chair is the motion for dissent from your ruling that my question was out of order.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walsh, I have suggested that you first withdraw your remarks in respect of a member of the other place. That is my ruling.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Walsh-Mr Deputy President, you may make that request when the motion now before the Chair has been disposed of, and that is the motion of dissent from your ruling.
Senator Cavanagh-I wish to speak to the point of order. I take it, Mr Deputy President, that Senator Walsh dissented from your ruling that he should withdraw certain remarks.
Senator Walsh-No, the ruling that the question is out of order.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cavanagh, I have asked Senator Walsh to withdraw. When he has done that we will deal with the other matter. It is the Chair's prerogative to ask a senator to withdraw unparliamentary language.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Walsh-Mr Deputy President, I submit that everything that has transpired in this Senate since I moved dissent from your ruling that the question was out of order is itself out of order and that the Senate has no option but to proceed with the motion of dissent from your ruling.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walsh, I asked you to withdraw. I am in charge of this House and I asked you to withdraw first those remarks in respect of--

As a result, the issue must be resolved on the very basis of your own ruling before we can get to the question of whether Senator Walsh is obliged to withdraw. If the motion of dissent from your ruling is defeated then, with respect, it will be open to you to request that Senator Walsh withdraw, but not before.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I asked Senator Walsh to withdraw because he used unparliamentary language against a member of the other place. That is the first thing that I put before the Senate. I have asked Senator Walsh to withdraw.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Walsh-I decline to withdraw, Mr Deputy President, since you decline to abide by the Standing Orders. In doing so I draw your attention to the latter part of the question I asked on 5 December. It reads:

Will the Deputy Leader of the Government ask the Prime Minister whether public documents reveal that up to 1 November this year a family company of the Minister for Communications was the custodian and beneficiary of 300,000 misappropriated dollars and whether the Prime Minister approves of the use of misappropriated funds as working capital for private ministerial businesses? If the Prime Minister does not so approve, why did he reappoint Mr Sinclair to the Cabinet?

Mr Deputy President, if that question was acceptable to the President on 5 December 1980 and if it was apparently acceptable to Senator Durack, the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate, who said he would refer that question to the Prime Minister, I submit that the question which I just asked is equally acceptable.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not present in the chair on that occasion. I stick to my ruling on the Standing Orders. I ask you to withdraw those remarks against a member of another place.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Walsh-I note that there is one difference in the wording, although of similar meaning. In the earlier question I referred to 300,000 misappropriated dollars. Today I referred to 200,000 stolen dollars, $100,000 of the amount having been paid back since the earlier question was asked. I am quite willing to withdraw the word 'stolen' and to substitute the word 'misappropriated'.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —No. Senator Walsh, you will withdraw unreservedly your remarks using the words 'stolen goods' against a member in another place.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Grimes-You have to look after your mates.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I would look after anyone under these circumstances. Senator Walsh, I ask you to withdraw.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Walsh-No, Mr Deputy President. My reasons--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —In that case, Senator Walsh, I name you.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Walsh-On 6 June 1975--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walsh, I have no option but to name you. You are defying the Chair.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Walsh-He admitted that money his father had stolen--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! You are defying the Chair. I have asked you to withdraw. I name you.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Walsh- . . . was paid into his family company and he still had it, and he still has it.
Senator Carrick-I have no other recourse than to ask that in accordance with Standing Order 440 Senator Walsh be called upon to make any explanation or apology he thinks fit.

Senator Walsh-Mr Deputy President, these proceedings are out of order, as has been everything that has transpired in this Senate since I moved dissent from your ruling that my question was out of order. Having already entered a caveat about that, I draw your attention to a number of other matters which are already on the public record. The relevant sequence of events is this: On 6 June 1979, following a number of public disclosures and a number of debates, both in this Senate and in the House of Representatives, the present Minister for Communications publicly admitted that his father had misappropriated from the Reliance group of companies moneys in excess of $400,000. He also admitted that those moneys had been paid into the Sinclair Pastoral Co. Pty Ltd of which he was the primary beneficiary. A deed of arrangement issued by the present Minister for Communications on 1 August 1980 stated that under an agreement reached with members of the Walsh family the Minister undertook to forgo immediate claims for cash payment to his father's estate of $130,000 for accountancy and other fees due from the Reliance group of companies and agreed to repay, in three instalments, commencing with an instalment of $100,000 on 1 November last year, 300,000 additional dollars. Presumably since no public statement has been made, that $100,000 was paid on 1 November and $200,000 remains yet to be paid. That sequence of facts, which I stress came mostly from the mouth and the pen of the Minister concerned, prompted me to ask a question on 5 December last year, which reads in full:

My question to the Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate, who is representing the Prime Minister in this place, refers to a statement made in the House of Representatives on 6 June last year in which the present Minister for Communications acknowledged that several hundred thousand dollars misappropriated by G. M. Sinclair had been paid into the account of the Sinclair Pastoral Co. and that by a deed of arrangement dated 1 August 1979 the Minister agreed to repay $300,000 commencing on 1 November 1980. Will the Deputy Leader of the Government ask the Prime Minister whether public documents reveal that up to 1 November this year a family company of the Minister for Communications was the custodian and beneficiary of 300,000 misappropriated dollars and whether the Prime Minister approves of the use of misappropriated funds as working capital for private ministerial businesses? If the Prime Minister does not so approve, why did he reappoint Mr Sinclair to the Cabinet?

Senator Durack said:

The only substantial difference from the question I asked today-many might argue whether there was a substantial difference though there is some semantic difference-is that whereas previously I referred to 'misappropriated dollars', which are still, on his own public admission, in the custody of the present Minister for Communications, today I referred to 'stolen dollars'. I have already agreed to withdraw the reference to 'stolen dollars' and to substitute 'misappropriated dollars'. I do not believe that either the facts, which are not disputed by the Minister concerned, or the terms of the question, which were not objected to by the President or by anyone else when it was first asked on 5 December 1980, oblige me, Mr Deputy President, to go any further than I have done. I submit that the question ought to remain and that your naming of me be withdrawn. I also submit again that everything which has taken place in the Senate since I moved dissent from your ruling that the question was out of order, is itself out of order.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not concerned with what happened at some other period. The fact of the matter is that the honourable senator used unparliamentary language against a member in another place. That person has been exonerated in a court of law. All I ask the honourable senator to do is withdraw his statement. The reason I stated that the question was out of order was that the honourable senator used unparliamentary language. All I ask is that Senator Walsh withdraw those remarks concerning misappropriated or stolen funds or whatever the words were he used. The words are unparliamentary and I ask him to withdraw.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Walsh-I cannot withdraw what is true.
Senator Carrick-I ask once again, because I do not want to have to move the formal motion, that Senator Walsh withdraw his statement.
Senator Mason-Mr Deputy President. I raise a point of order. I think that Standing Order 429 is worth some consideration. It reads:

If any objection is taken to the ruling or decision of the President, such objection must be taken at once, and in writing, and Motion made, which, if seconded, shall be proposed to the Senate, and Debate thereon forthwith adjourned to the next sitting day, unless the Senate decides on motion, without Debate, that the Question requires immediate determination.
I assume, Mr Deputy President, that you have notice of the objection in writing. I did not hear the motion being seconded, though perhaps it was. I raise those points for your elucidation.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not relevant at the moment. We will deal with another subject before we get to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no recourse but to move, under section 440 of the Standing Orders:

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —All Senator Walsh said was that he had withdrawn the words 'stolen funds', and replaced them with the words 'misappropriated funds'. Perhaps the honourable senators can tell me the difference. I will be happy to know.

—I suggest that the question be taken at once.
—The question is that the motion be agreed to. Those of that opinion say aye.

TALK.START.PARA: —Might I recall the sequence of events. As I pointed out on a previous occasion, Mr Deputy President, you ruled Senator Walsh's question out of order with what I might describe as alacrity. Senator Rae may desire that honourable senators move with even greater alacrity than the Deputy President did on this occasion, but it is not the practice in this place. This is the earliest opportunity anyone in this chamber has properly had to deal with the question of dissent.

—Honourable senators, I could not have two motions before me at the same time. I asked Senator Walsh to withdraw. That is what was being discussed at the time. The reason I ruled his question out of order was that he used unparliamentary language, but I had to deal with that question first. Senator Button is in order in moving his motion.

—I wish to speak very briefly to this motion largely because much of the detail of it has been canvassed by Senator Walsh in some sort of limbo proceeding which we indulged in while other questions were being determined. The fact of the matter is that language in the Parliament does not become offensive just because--
—Order! Senator Button, the motion of dissent requires immediate determination. We cannot debate the issue.
—Mr Deputy President, you can hear argument on the motion. I draw your attention to Standing Order 430 which makes it very clear that you can hear argument on a motion of dissent.
—We have dealt with all of that. I have put the question.
—You have not, with respect, Mr Deputy President.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I put the question that the motion be agreed to and that is when a point of order was raised. The motion requires immediate determination, and I have just put the question that it be agreed to.

PROCTEXT.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Harradine from moving a motion affirming the validity of Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission Determination No. 503 of 1980 and deploring the Government's expressed intention to reject the Commission's decision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate affirms the validity of Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission Determination No. 503 of 1980 and deplores the Government's expressed intention to reject the Commission's decision.

One of the major matters facing this democracy in the latter part of the twentieth century is the question of the loyalty of the Public Service to the principles of democracy. It is a major tenet of democracy that those who are elected to govern ought to be in a position to claim the respect and loyalty of the public servants who are there to administer the laws of a democracy. However, I believe that the action of the Government in proposing to move dissent in the other place from the Arbitration Commission's Determination No. 503 after the public servants had gone through the processes of arbitration is doing little to enhance the claim by the Government for loyalty in the eyes of the Public Service. Last week we witnessed the unprecedented action of a relatively large group of Commonwealth public servants going on strike in protest against actions by this Government which the public servants saw as a threat to their conditions of service.

The Public Service Board might try to skate over what happened by claiming that only a certain percentage of public servants actually engaged in strike activity and absented themselves last Tuesday, but the more relevant point is that those absent from work represented the largest number of public servants to go on strike in the history of the Public Service. What is happening is that the Government is engaged in a line of attack which has the effect of promoting the politicisation of the Public Service unions. I would like to think that the Government is not doing this deliberately but is quite unconscious of the effects of its actions. But the more I study the problem the more I come to the conclusion that this Government is not very concerned about the damage that it is doing to responsible unionism. Rather, it has seized upon the Public Service as an area where it will be extremely provocative, and when public servants react it will come crashing down like a ton of bricks upon them, all for the purpose of electoral public relations.

Previous provocative actions by this Government have resulted in a turn-round of the leadership of the largest Public Service union, namely, the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association. That union had leaders who were progressive and quite vocal in the fields of negotiation and arbitration but, because of the attitudes of and actions taken by the Government, this union is now under the control, in a number of States, of what are called militants. I refer to them as Volvo-socialists and white wine whingers. But responsible union leaders who pinned their faith to the way of the arbiter now have the retort shouted at them: 'But look what happened. We went to arbitration and now the Government wants to throw out the Full Bench's determination. We were told to go to the arbitrator-to the umpire-and now the Government, not being satisfied with the umpire's decision, seeks to disallow that decision by using its numbers in the House of Representatives'.

It is interesting indeed that the Government has chosen the House of Representatives in which to move dissent from this determination of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and not the Senate, although it is basing its dissent on an opinion given by the Attorney-General (Senator Durack). I will speak about that a little more at a later stage. I do not deny that the Parliament has the power under the Public Service Arbitration Act to reject determinations from the Arbitrator, but I point out that of perhaps the tens of thousands of determinations which have been tabled in this Parliament only four have been rejected. I remind honourable senators of the statement by the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, Mr Viner. He declared that this particular determination ought to be dissented from. So far as I can recall-and honourable senators may correct me if I am wrong-the Minister made a statement that the determination was accompanied by a letter from Mr R. H. C. Watson, Acting Public Service Arbitrator, which stated that he was of the opinion that these determinations were not or might not be in accordance with the following laws of the Commonwealth, namely, the Public Service Act 1922 and the Public Service Salaries Regulations.

As I recall it, Mr Viner made great play of the fact that that letter had been attached to determinations nos 503 and 504 to be tabled in this House. But let me remind the Senate that last year 400 determinations from the Public Service Arbitrator were tabled in the Senate and that 329 of those were accompanied by the same statement or similar statements by the Arbitrator-that they may or may not be in accordance with the law of the Commonwealth. The Government advances a trite sort of argument. It says that just because it is par for the course for an arbitrator to attach such a statement to a determination it is grounds for a determination to be disallowed. This determination has that statement attached to it. In that statement the Arbitrator says that it may not be in accordance with the Public Service Act. But the Attorney-General, in his statement, says that it is not in accordance with the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act. Last year, 400 determinations provided no problem to senators and to members of the House of Representatives and none was disallowed. So why all the fuss about Determination No. 503? I suggest that it has a great deal to do with symbolism and electoral public relations. I suggest that the appropriate course for this Parliament is to let No. 503 proceed and if the Government really believes that it is contrary to the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act it can challenge it in the High Court. That is the place where the Government should challenge the determination; it should not use its numbers in this Parliament against the umpire's decision.

Further evidence that the Government's case is extremely weak is found in the fact that this question of whether or not Determination 503 is or may be contrary to the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act was discussed by the Full Bench of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. I refer to the tabled documents which comprise a copy of the determination, a copy of the covering letter by the Acting Public Service Arbitrator-such a letter accompanies almost every determination that comes into this chamber-and a statement by Senator Durack. But Senator Durack is not even in this chamber to defend his opinion. He knows that his opinion is really simply a rehash of the particular laws of the Parliament. There are very few words of opinion in it other than the expression of opinion that the receptive provisions of Determination No. 503 and of the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act are in direct conflict in that the Act obliges the permanent head and the Board respectively to issue instruments in certain circumstances whereas the determination provides that they shall not do so unless other circumstances have occurred. Senator Durack went on in his statement with a number of other matters.

But the question of whether the determination was in accord with the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act was canvassed before the Full Bench of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The Full Bench of the Commission said:

. . . a determination giving the applicants rights relating to consultation and prescribing periods of time for various procedures would not be out of 'accord' with the Redeployment and Retirement Act.

There we have the learned judges of the Full Bench, this question having been canvassed before them, stating that their determination would not be out of accord with the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act. Yet the Attorney-General of this Commonwealth came into this chamber, tabled a statement and then shot out of the chamber. He was not game enough to stay and defend it against the opinion of the judges of the Full Bench of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Whose opinion are we to have respect for? Are we to respect the opinion of the members of the Full Bench of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission before whom all of these points were laid out and before whom senior counsel from both sides-from the Government and from the unions-put forward their viewpoints, and who decided that their determination would not be out of accord with the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act? Or are we to respect the opinions of a Minister who comes into this chamber with a piece of paper, throws it on the table of the Senate and then darts out of the chamber and is not game enough to come back in and defend it? Under those circumstances whom are we to place faith in?

The Attorney-General claimed in his statement accompanying the Determination that it is out of accord. Let the Attorney-General come before this Senate and let him argue against what the Full Bench of his own Conciliation and Arbitration Commission has said and so do it justice if he is not prepared to do the Senate justice because in my view it is an insult to the Full Bench of the Commission for an Attorney-General to act in the way that Senator Durack has acted. Remember also that the Arbitrator in his statement accompanying the Determination did not mention the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act. He did not say that the Determination was contrary to that Act. He cited the Public Service Act as the one with which it is or may be out of accord. The Attorney-General, from what I have seen in the short time that I have had to read his opinion, does not say that it is out of accord with the Public Service Act. He does say that the Determination is not in accord with a law of the Commonwealth, namely, the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act 1979. The Arbitrator did not say that it is out of accord with that piece of legislation. Why is there this difference? There is obviously a conflict of opinion between the Attorney-General and the Arbitrator and between the Attorney-General and the Full Bench of the Commission before which these matters were canvassed and which stated that the procedures laid down by Determination No. 503 would not be out of accord with the Act.

Surely the proper way for this matter to be resolved is to facilitate its coming before the High Court. Let not the Government use its numbers in the House of Representatives. The Government is not game enough to put a dissent motion in this Senate. The Government will do it in the House of Representatives where it has got the numbers in bags full. Surely the proper way would be not to use its numbers in a matter in which there is an obvious conflict between the opinion of the Attorney-General and the Full Bench of the Commission. Surely the best way for this to be resolved would be to facilitate the matter coming before the High Court which would mean leaving the Determination alive at least for such a challenge to proceed. I am asking the Senate to act not in a manner which is out of character but in its usual manner to allow this Determination to have effect.

DISALLOWANCE OF DETERMINATION 503 OF 1980
Outlined below is a brief summary of 'gains' made by Determination 503 of 1980 which will be subject to disallowance.

Obligation on Public Service Board to provide all relevant details to unions involved including an outline of significant changes in Department's functions or operations which caused the redundancy situation and information on vacant positions.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts, I present the 184th report of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a short statement in connection with the report.
