TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee's 184th report is the product of a long-standing interest it has had in public administration, in particular the quality of information available to management on which it bases its decisions. Perhaps I should digress a little to the historical interest of the Committee. In July 1964, following comment in the Auditor-General's report for 1962-63 and subsequently in the Committee's 66th report, all departments were instructed by the Department of the Treasury to examine critically tasks being undertaken by internal audit staff and to ensure that sufficient staff were maintained for the proper performance of the audit function. Further continuing references by the Auditors-General to deficiencies led the Committee to conduct a general inquiry into internal audit in 1971. The results of that inquiry were reported to Parliament in its 139th report in September 1972. The Committee noted improvements had occurred in some departments but was disturbed by the use of internal audit staff on other duties.

SPEECH.PARA: In July 1973, the Public Service Board drew the attention of all departments to the Committee's comments and a year later followed up with a survey seeking information on the measures taken to ensure the effective performance of the internal audit function. Nevertheless, criticism by Auditors-General has continued. A joint management review of internal audit procedures was commissioned by the Public Service Board in 1977. This review involved a study of internal audit practices in seven large departments and eight major companies and public authorities in Australia, and included an evaluation of practices adopted overseas. The results were conveyed to the Board in late 1977 and, after circulation of the report to all permanent heads and discussions with the Auditor-General, a series of recommendations were put forward in April 1979. Aspects of this report are discussed in chapter 6 of this paper. It is a fundamental requirement that in order to obtain the maximum in efficiency, effectiveness and economic operations an enterprise must have an effective internal control. Internal audit is just one facet of those internal controls, and is a powerful management tool in assisting management to reach even higher goals.

Whilst there is a pressing need for effective internal auditing, the application for which it is of the greatest importance is automatic data processing. The expanding use and increasing complexity of systems and the potential magnitude of waste and losses if internal controls are defective or deficient, makes effective internal auditing an indispensable requirement. Controls in data processing must be monitored frequently, in some cases continuously, using specialised internal audit routines. Although these audit routines provide greater assurance for the external auditor, the responsibility for their development and implementation properly belongs within individual organisations. ADP auditing problems are severe. The installation of audit needs at design and implementation stages of systems development may be difficult technically and costly, but senior management must beware of the negative comments of systems designers and take advice on these matters from skilled ADP auditors. Considering the scarcity of such auditors, the need to rationalise their availability and use with the public service becomes apparent.

Apart from the importance of internal auditing to ADP, there is a need for the effective review and appraisal of all operations and verification procedures. Internal auditing must also be concerned with ongoing reviews of overall organisational performance in a manner acceptable to senior management, although not necessarily to line management. It must include assessments, verification and the sponsoring of suggestions for improvement. Its sucess will rely upon access to senior management, a broad charter for the review of operations, and the technological capability to review and analyse performance. Ulti- mately it should provide a comprehensive feedback facility to support managements' financial and decision making systems. Management may then determine whether government policies and the objectives, goals and plans of the organisation are being achieved in the manner intended.

This discussion paper looks at some of the problems of internal audit, ranging from its historical background to the work being undertaken at present to increase its effectiviness. The Committee wishes to emphasise that the recommendations it has put forward do not cover all that is needed to bring about effective analysis, review, appraisal, control and verification of public sector functions and activities. It hopes that this paper will stimulate further consideration of the broader dimensions of the problem and suggestions for the development of a balanced approach towards achieving a solution. It is patently obvious to the Committee that previous attempts to improve internal audit in the Australian Public Service have been generally unsuccessful. It is just as clear that those failures resulted from insufficient interest on the part of permanent and statutory heads and a lack of support for internal audit by senior management, a situation exacerbated by the low standard of internal audit itself.

The findings of the 1977 review focused attention on the dismal state of internal audit in the Public Service and stimulated renewed efforts to bring about improvements. The Public Service Board has initiated action designed to upgrade internal audit. Its success will depend entirely on the support given by individual departments and authorities and the steps taken to ensure that the improvements necessary in their own organisations are vigorously pursued. It is essential that the heads of departments and authorities cultivate a genuine interest in internal audit and learn to use it effectively. The tendency for many permanent heads to concentrate on policy matters and ignore administrative and financial affairs cannot be condoned.

The Public Accounts Committee is committed to ensuring the necessary improvements in internal audit are brought about. The Committee will use every opportunity to check progress within departments and test the commitment of permanent and statutory heads and management toward an effective internal audit. It also plans to intitate a review of internal audit to evaluate progress with the improvement program within selected departments and authorities during the current Parliament. The Committee is keenly interested in ongoing developments in all spheres of internal audit and welcomes any suggestions, information or comments in response to the report. I commend the report to honourable senators and trust that it will be a useful document and provokes the discussion it is intended to provoke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The internal audit is an integral part of the overall internal control procedures of an organisation. These internal control procedures are the means by which the management can safeguard assets and ensure accuracy and reliability of the financial operating statements and operational efficiency. For quite some years now the Auditor-General has been quite concerned about the standard of internal auditing within the public sector. That concern has been shared by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. A significant development occurred with the consultants report in 1977 known as the Coopers Lybrand report. As Senator Lajovic has just stated, the consultants examined seven major departments and eight major companies and statutory organisations as well as overseas operations. The consultants were fairly critical of the state of internal auditing. There were some 600 internal auditors and the cost at that time exceeded something like $7m. This included travel costs in addition to salaries. They felt that in terms of value for money they were unable to identify sufficient tangible benefits from the then current internal audit staff or the procedures they used. This was indeed a sad indictment, I believe, of the level, at that stage, of internal audit within the public sector. Since that time the Public Service Board has moved, some believe too slowly. Nevertheless, it has taken some steps to remedy some of these earlier criticisms. However, it was almost two years, I think, before a major response was made. This was mainly in the area of education. It was contained in a circular issued in 1979 and was designed to encourage departments and authorities to improve the efficiency of the internal audit system.

SPEECH.PARA: Our Public Accounts Committee has launched into new ground with today's issue of the 184th report. This is the first of what we hope will be a series of discussion papers on matters of importance in the public sector and particularly in matters of administration. The Committee's authority, of course, is derived from section 8 of the Public Accounts Committee Act of 1951. One of our recommendations is that there should be a pool of internal auditors highly skilled in the more specialised audit procedures and techniques. The Joint Committee of Public Accounts, which comprises senators and members of the House of Representatives, has examined, in some recent reports, some of the problems arising in the high technology areas. In the area of automatic data processing the Committee has been very concerned about the shortcomings inherent in some major installations. As a result the Committee came up with a report concerning the acquisition of computers where it was concerned at the tremendous cost to the Government in delayed acquisition procedures.

That was followed by a report on Mandata which concerned the fiasco of the Public Service Board's entering into a highly sophisticated ADP complex area where it was caught in all sorts of difficulties including high turnover of staff. Basically the Board was dealing in an area with which it was unfamiliar and which resulted in tremendous cost to the Government. The Committee then followed up with a further report on overpayments to pharmacists. We have to recognise that the computing area is growing. We now have over 80 medium sized and large scale computers. The big problem is the shortage of adequate trained staff. The shortage is particularly acute in the automatic data processing area. It is not a problem that is peculiar to Australia; it is found throughout the world. Fortunately, steps are being taken to improve the level of ADP internal auditing. It is only fairly recently that the public sector has moved with any haste in this area at all.

I am pleased that the Board announced-I think it was in December last year-that Dr Brian Garner, Professor of Computing at Deakin University, had been seconded to provide an advanced course in automatic data processing. I mentioned this as significant to overcome serious lack of expertise. I personally believe a further way of overcoming the serious lack of expertise is for the Public Service Board to offer not less than 20 places for specialised, advanced postgraduate courses in ADP such as are offered by the Caulfield Institute of Technology or by some of the newer universities to young graduates. It is unfortunate that the universities and institutes of technology have moved so slowly in providing appropriate courses in this fast growing area of technology. The problems of recruitment will remain because on the basis of employment of about 600 internal auditors we have to recruit around 120 to 150 people at least to the internal audit sections each year to maintain current levels.

The days of individual checking with the routine of an auditor green ticking each individual item are gone. Nowadays there is a move from what we term financial or compliance auditing towards efficiency auditing. We hope that ulti- mately the next move will be to develop to program auditing or the auditing of specific programs. I believe there is a need for a general upgrading in the role of the internal auditor not only at the bottom but also at the highest possible level. In fact there is the need for an appropriate classification for the chief internal auditor to at least Second Division, Level One so that the job is provided with the appropriate status. This internal auditor must report to top management. One of the difficulties in the past has concerned the appropriate role of the internal auditor. In the past some of the departmental heads, unfortunately, have been more concerned with policy matters than with administration. This is one of the reasons why in the past insufficient attention has been given to the need and to the importance of the correct role of the internal auditor. He should play an integral part in reporting to top management. Top management has been concerned about the role of internal auditing as compared with other functions such as management organisation systems. Whilst it is important for the internal auditor to report to the top management about deficiencies, the scope of the audit and improvements in organisational procedure, it is important that the internal auditor be not involved with the actual implementation of those programs.

Our Committee has come up with recommendations that audit committees should be formed. This has the advantage of collecting and disseminating information. With the creating of committees and permitting a greater rotation of internal auditors within the public sector, the status of these professionals will be increased. Where a proper system of internal audit is operating external auditors can place much more reliance upon control procedures and adjust their programs accordingly.

I believe in the future there is good scope for young people to enter the Public Service via the internal auditing functions and work their way up into top management positions. This PAC report has broken new ground in the area of accountability. While the internal auditor is responsible to top management the external auditor is responsible to the Parliament. It is important to note that there is a very strong relationship between the Auditor-General's Office and the Public Accounts Committee. Mr Hill recently said that the relationship has been close but never cosy. I commend to the Parliament this discussion paper which breaks new ground in reporting to the Parliament.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Reference to Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matters be referred to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs for inquiry and report as soon as possible:
(a) the circumstances surrounding the floating of Negri River Corporation Limited in October and November 1980;

(b) the adequacy of the prospectus issued by the company on 15 October 1980 and in particular the question as to whether a geological report by Dr Peter Solomon in relation to the areas the subject of exploration licences acquired by the company should have been included or referred to in that prospectus;
(c) the role of the Sydney Stock Exchange in relation to the listing of and subsequent trading in shares in the company;
(d) the role of the New South Wales Corporate Affairs Commission in relation to the registration of the prospectus and the subsequent investigation of the affairs of the company;

(e) the adequacy of the powers of the National Companies and Securities Commission under the new co-operative companies and securities scheme to protect investors in relation to speculative ventures of this kind; and
(f) the adequacy of present and proposed new company and securities law provisions to protect investors in relation to such ventures.

It appears that there is rather less support for these matters to be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs than was apparent when the matters were first raised last week. I think that is a great pity because the issues involved are major and of potentially quite explosive significance. In the past the Senate has played a leadership role and has developed in that respect a fine national reputation in exposing corporate malpractice and identifying the kinds of legislative and administrative solutions that are appropriate to deal with it. I am referring, of course, to the Select Committee on Securities and Exchange which was chaired by Senator Rae. I believe it would be an abdication of responsibility for the Senate now, in dealing with this motion, to pretend that the issues underlying it do not exist, to put it in the too-hard basket or simply to defer indefinitely consideration of these matters in the hope that they will go away.

At the moment Australia is involved in exactly the same kind of mining and resources-led boom, an overheated stock exchange boom, that existed in the late 1960s and the early 1970s. There has been the same kind of increase-indeed almost a doubling-in the ordinary share indices in the last two years, as there was with a doubling of the index in the period from 1967 to 1969. It is the kind of boom that has resulted in a massive degree of insider trading, other financial malpractice and spreading of misinformation as occurred in the 1970s. That kind of boom situation gives rise to the potential for exactly the same sequence of events. We are now seeing the return of the speculative float, this time not with respect to nickel but diamonds. What kicked off the present situation more than anything else was undoubtedly the Ashton consortium's finds in the Lake Argyle area of the Kimberleys in 1979. Honourable senators will be aware that it was announced last week that those findings were of such a size they may add something like 50 per cent to the world's known diamond reserves.

That discovery has brought in its train quite a feverish burst of activity, the taking up of leases, the engaging in exploration activity on the ground and the recent announcement of plans to establish a major diamond cutting and polishing venture in Perth and some very keen interest has been shown in making new company floats. The Negri River float is so far the daddy of them all so far as speculative diamond ventures go, but it will not necessarily be the daddy of those to come if the present predictions as to the nature and potential of diamond exploration activity in the north-west of Australia come to fruition. One of the main underlying justifications for moving this motion at this time is to throw the spotlight on the kind of commercial activity that is possibly going on in respect of these speculative floats and to cut off right at the outset, before it gets out of hand in the way that it did, regrettably, in the late 1960s and early 1970s, the kind of corporate misbehaviour that then took place.

The details of the Negri float are quite complex. They are made more so by the consideration that not all the facts are on public record and the fact that to the extent that matters have been put on public record, the validity of many of them is by no means uncontested. That said, the basic issues are quite simple. First, was there a deliberate non-disclosure in the prospectus that was issued for the company of a geological report which might significantly have influenced the decision of investors contemplating participating in this speculative float? Secondly, was there insider trading in the form of profit taking by at lease some of those who took up private allotments of shares prior to the public subscription being opened and who knew of the unfavourable geological report in question and took advantage of the non-disclosure of this very price-sensitive information? Thirdly, have the deficiencies in the substance of our companies and securities law, which were identified by the Rae committee in 1974, been corrected either in the present law or that proposed as part of the new co-operative companies and securities scheme so that with the coming to fruition of the co-operative scheme an effective weapon will be available against behaviour of this general kind-I beg no questions about this particular matter-to the extent that it occurred in this case? Fourthly, have the deficiencies in the administration of companies and securities law which were identified, again by the Rae Committee, in 1974 been corrected in the activities or the development of the various State Corporate Affairs Commissions and will the new structure to exist under the umbrella of the National Companies and Securities Commission be effective to investigate and deal quickly with possible breaches of the law, again in this general area?

They are the issues. What are the possible facts? I say 'possible' because it is not my purpose to make judicial pronouncements about the kinds of matters that have been claimed to exist. That is part of the reason why I want this matter to be inquired into by a Senate committee with the resources available to it to take evidence on oath and to determine where in fact the truth lies. What is involved essentially is as follows: The areas in issue span some 2,452 square kilometres. They are covered by the Northern Territory mining leases Nos 2092 and 2093, which abut the border of Western Australia some 100 kilometres south-east of the Lake Argyle finds. The leases in question are in the Ord River catchment area, but upstream from the Lake Argyle area where diamonds were found. Senator Puplick, who I understand is to speak later in this debate, will no doubt be able to discourse more learnedly on the geological characteristics of the areas in question. For the moment I just note the general proximity of the leases in question to the Argyle finds.

Let us consider the sequence of events. Things really began with the leases in question being pegged out by Mr Graham Beith, a businessman who has a long involvement in various capacities in the mining industry and who remains a central figure in the tale thereafter. In April 1979 Mr Beith established a syndicate with Mr David Lance, who was a stockbroker and member of the firm of Norths in Sydney, which comes into the picture later as the underwriter to the speculative issue involved in the flotation of Negri River Corporation Ltd. The third member of the syndicate was Mr Campbell Cooper. They applied for exploration licences 2092 and 2093. On 25 July 1979 what has become known as the Solomon report was signed. This report was prepared by Dr Solomon and Mr A. J. O'Toole of the firm of International Resources Consultants Pty Ltd in Sydney. It was based on some 10 days field work involving air reconnaissance and some on-the-ground geological investigation of areas of the leases. The report in question was commissioned jointly by Mr Graham Beith and Mr Frank Nugan, who is but one of a numerous cast of colourful characters who seem to have been involved in this exercise at various stages. The point about the Solomon report, as is foreshadowed in the terms of the motion, is that it was negative so far as diamond prospects were concerned for the area of the leases in question. The report concluded that further exploration was unwarranted in relation to these leases. It stated:

Field and laboratory investigations have revealed no evidence to support the thesis that the regions under review represent a geological environment conducive to the location of either primary or secondary deposits of diamonds.

On 10 September 1979 exploration licences 2092 and 2093 were granted nonetheless to Messrs Beith, Lance and Cooper, as tenants in common to the extent of some 33 1/3 per cent interest each. On 21 December 1979, a dispute of some kind having arisen between Mr Beith and the other members of the syndicate, the resolution of which dispute Mr Beith seems to have thought might have been helped by the intervention of Sir Asher Joel, who comes into the picture at this stage. Mr Beith sold some 50 per cent of his interest in the licences to Design and Construction Consultants Pty Ltd, a firm owned and controlled by Sir Asher Joel and his family. The shareholders in that company were Sir Asher Joel, Lady Joel, Dr Michael Joel, Alexander Joel and Fotheringham Investments Pty Ltd. It appears that at the time of the sale of half his interest in the licences in question, Mr Beith claims to have handed over to Sir Asher Joel's solicitors, Messrs Lane and Lane, all the documents in his possession relating to the lease area in question. I understand from Mr Beith's account that that bundle of documents included the Solomon report.

It is on the basis of the inclusion of the Solomon report, among other things, in those documents, that Mr Beith seeks to establish as a fact-there are other reasons, apparently, to justify this; this is one of the matters that will need to be untangled by the Committee if it ever deals with this case-that at least Sir Asher Joel, as a later vendor of those licences, knew of the extent of the Solomon report.

It has been claimed by Mr Beith-again, this is a matter that will need to be tested-that in conversation in Darwin in January 1980 it was agreed between Mr Beith and Sir Asher Joel that it would be impossible to undertake a public float on leases 2092 and 2093 at a later date without revealing the existence of the Solomon report. On the face of it that is a plausible enough proposition, given its negative character and its obvious implications for investors who might be moved to invest in this area. I should mention, of course, as ought to be implicit from what I said earlier, that in the intervening period there had been the discovery of significant diamond deposits in the Lake Argyle area downstream from this lease area. So the Solomon report, to that extent, had to be looked at in the light of those subsequent discoveries, but nonetheless it is claimed that it was well understood as between Mr Beith and Sir Asher Joel that the Solomon report would have to feature prominently in any public information given about these leases which might endeavour to support a flotation of the company.

On 25 January 1980 Mr Beith sold the remaining 50 per cent of his interest to Design and Construction Pty Ltd for a sum of $10,000, this transaction being part again, apparently, of the ongoing negotiations between him and Sir Asher Joel and his former partners to reach some kind of amicable settlement of a rather complex litigation situation which had then developed. In addition to the $10,000, Mr Beith claims that he retained, as part of that agreement, to sell a 15 per cent royalty interest in leases 2092 and 2093. So in terms of what we will come to in a moment, the amount of the potential royalty flow involved, that is not insignificant continuing interest. On 16 July 1980 the Negri River company was in fact incorporated in New South Wales, its directors being Sir Davis Hughes as Chairman, Mr Geoffrey Kelvin Gray as Deputy Chairman with Dr Brian Marshall, geologist, and Mr Michael Murray Hornibrook, solicitor, as the remaining two directors.

On 28 July 1980 there was a sale of the exploration licences to the newly established company by the possessors of those licences, namely Design and Construction Pty Ltd and Messrs Lance and Cooper. They sold out, it appears, the whole of their interest in those licences to the company, the basic quid pro quo being $90,000 by way of reimbursement for exploration expenditure claimed to have occurred and, more significantly perhaps, a royalty interest amounting to 12 per cent annually of the net profit before tax that might be raised by the venture up to a maximum of $12m per annum. That is the nature and extent of the royalty interest that is here involved.

On 5 August 1980 the transfer of licences from these vendors to the company was registered by the Director of Mines of the Northern Territory. On 2 September 1980, there was a crucial transaction-an allotment of 3,499,994 ordinary shares at 20c each for cash to a miscellaneous group of members of the Joel family, Sir Asher Joel's company, Lindfield Enterprises Pty Ltd, Mr Lance, Mr Cooper and, it appears, Mr Graham Beith, to the extent of some 15,000 shares-shares, incidentally, which Mr Beith claims not to have subsequently traded, despite the temptation to do so when their price escalated out of all subsequent recognition. So there was a private allotment of nearly 3.5 million shares, less the handful of shares held by the existing directors. Three and a half million shares, in effect, were privately alloted to the vendors of the licences and, in particular, various members of the Joel family.

On 10 September the licences for the lease areas were renewed for 12 months. On 10 October an underwriting agreement was entered into between the company and Norths Securities Pty Ltd, the stockbroking firm of which, it will be remembered, Mr Lance was a member. On 10 October there was a geological report signed by Professor Allan Voisey, whose bona fides and reputability, I hasten to add, are absolutely in no way in issue in anything, either explicitly or implicitly, that might be said. Professor Voisey, in his geological report which accompanied the prospectus, indicated a rather more optimistic view of the likely exploration prospects of the lease areas. His report, it appears, were based on some direct visit to the area in question, combined with an extensive analysis of Landsat satellite photographs which bring to light the geological character of the area. He makes it clear that it is also based squarely on the conclusions which might be thought to flow simply from the fact of the discoveries in the relatively nearby Lake Argyle area. His language in this report is cautious, as is best indicated, I think, simply by quoting, from the whole of the report, only one paragraph which is the actual recommendation. It states:

Because of the announced discovery of kimberlite and diamonds near Lake Argyle, it would be fair to say that the country and the gravel deposits covered by the Ord River catchment have been upgraded as diamond prospects. I recommend that Negri River Corporation Ltd, having regard to the presence within the Licence area of extensive alluvial deposits, and of major structural features which could have provided channelways for kimberlite-placement, should commence a detailed exploration programme on the Licence Area.

Throughout the language of the report there are words such as 'could', 'possibly', and 'upgraded'. This is the kind of language which appears. There is no more a substantial recommendation than that, but perhaps no more substantial recommendation, based on the information then to hand, could have been expected from a competent geologist. On 15 October, following the production of that report, and the flurry of preceding activity no doubt, a prospectus was issued as the condition precedent to public flotation of the company. That prospectus had been registered beforehand at the New South Wales Corporate Affairs Commission. It was a prospectus which, in familiar form, sets out all the necessary basic information and contains the geologist's report in quite extensive detail, plus a page of material on the question as to prior exploration of the licence area, to which I will refer again-a page of material, the significance of which I note for the moment only in the terms that it contains no reference whatsoever to the Solomon report.

In late October the following things happened: Mr Beith read in the newspapers, first of all, of the prospectus having been issued; he, according to his own account, rang Dr Michael Joel and drew Dr Joel's attention, or reminded Dr Joel, depending on how one chooses to interpret the situation, of the existence of the Solomon report and its implications for the proposed float, and was told by Dr Michael Joel that it was none of Mr Beith's business. Mr Beith then obtained the prospectus, read it carefully, and again rang Dr Michael Joel saying that he would in fact inform the Stock Exchange and the Corporate Affairs Commission of absence of referral to the Solomon report if some steps were not taken to inform the potential investing public of the existence of that report so that it could make up its mind accordingly. Again it appears or it is claimed by Mr Beith that he was told that it was none of his business and that the whole thing was in fact committed and under way and that nothing he did would change that circumstance.

Then, it appears, Mr Beith rang Mr Willis of the New South Wales Corporate Affairs Commission, this being about 21 to 23 October-a date of that kind-and told him of the existence of the Solomon report and secured a reaction from that officer to the effect that the Corporate Affairs Commission would investigate the matters in issue. On 4 November subscription lists opened for the public flotation, and indeed closed immediately thereafter, I understand, on that day with the issue fully subscribed. The number of shares issued in this way by public subscription amounted to another 3.5 million at a par value of 20c, the total issued capital thus added up to seven million shares at 20c each, half of those initially by private allotment before the float, the remaining 3.5 million at 20c each by public subscription.

A couple of weeks later, on 20 November, the company's shares were listed for trading on the Sydney Stock Exchange. They took off immediately, being traded at around $2 a share and getting up in fact to $2.35 on the second day of trading. It has been claimed by various people and in the Press that Sir Asher Joel and the other persons who have received, in particular, substantial private allotments proceeded to trade rather busily in that particular period and to take the very substantial profits that are associated with an increase in a share price from 20c to about $2. Whether profits were taken on any significant scale by Sir Asher Joel and the other people associated with the vending of the licences and that private allotment remains to be determined. I note that some Press accounts have suggested that the purchasers of a good many of the shares thus traded by Sir Asher Joel in the first instance were others of his own companies and that indeed no more than some circular book entries may have been involved in the process. But they are among the things that remain to be untangled if this matter proceeds to a proper investigation.

On the day of the listing it appears that Mr Beith telephoned a gentleman in a senior position at the Melbourne Stock Exchange and told him of the existence of the Solomon report and his concern that the matter had proceeded to public listing without the Corporate Affairs Commission or, it appears, anyone else in Sydney having taken any action to stop it. It was at this stage that Mr Beith, by his own account, was told in fairly colourful language: 'Son, you are up against the establishment. Take your money and run'. Later in November, it having become clear that no Corporate Affairs Commission action or stock exchange action seemed likely to occur then, Mr Beith took his concerns, via his own solicitor, to the Press. It was at that stage, right at the end of November, that the matter, and the existence of the Solomon report, became public knowledge for the first time.

I should make it clear that on 28 November the directors of the Negri company made a statement to the stock exchange. That statement is on the files of the stock exchange and subsequently was made available to the Press. The directors made a statement to the stock exchange, through their chairman Sir Davis Hughes, that they were unaware of the Solomon report's existence. On 12 December the text of the Solomon report was apparently given by Mr Beith to the Sydney Stock Exchange. In the interim some kind of investigation-precisely what remains unclear-had been carried out by the New South Wales Corporate Affairs Commission, but on 3 February 1981 the nature of that investigation by the New South Wales Corporate Affairs Commission was substantially upgraded by virtue of the Attorney-General's directing a special investigation to take place which then enabled the powers under the New South Wales companies legislation for gathering of information on oath and so on to be set in train. That exercise by the New South Wales Corporate Affairs Commission is proceeding at this stage with some kind of report apparently being expected within the next few weeks. The Sydney Stock Exchange responded to the public disclosures made by Mr Beith and others by commencing its own investigation which was announced on 2 December last year, but the Sydney Stock Exchange has not at any stage suspended trading in the shares of the company and it is not known to me certainly what, if anything, is likely to emerge from the investigations of that exchange.

It is a long story but obviously, just on the bare face of that account, some very important issues are raised by it. Let me just indicate as briefly as I can, because I do not want to burden the Senate unduly, some of the legal issues which seem to be squarely raised by these facts, if indeed they are facts. I hasten to add that I am in no position to make any assertions as to the accuracy or otherwise of the various things that have been claimed. Statements have been put on the record by various parties, most of whom have an interest of one kind or another in the outcome. Their veracity will have to be tested in an appropriate forum which again is one of the reasons I have moved this motion.

First of all, there are the problems about non-disclosure in the prospectus. Under section 46 (1) of the uniform companies Acts, which is the existing company law legislation, there is provision for civil liability for loss suffered by reason of the wilful non-disclosure of material matter in a prospectus. That obligation falls upon every person who, having had knowledge of the matter in question, is a director, causes himself to be named as a director, has agreed to become a director, is a promoter of the corporation or is a person who authorised or caused the issue of the prospectus. There is an almost equivalent provision in clause 107 of the new co-operative scheme companies Bill which has been tabled in this Parliament. The other non-disclosure provision which seems to be relevant is section 47 (1) of the existing uniform scheme which imposes substantial criminal liability for any untrue statement or wilful non-disclosure in a prospectus upon any person who authorised or caused the issue of the prospectus unless that person can prove that the statement or non-disclosure was immaterial or believed by him on reasonable grounds to be immaterial. The prescribed penalty at the moment is one year's gaol or $2,000 fines. In clause 108 of the new national companies Bill, if I can so describe it, there is an almost identical provision for which the penalty has been upgraded to 5 years' gaol or fines of $20,000, there being a new exclusion for inadvertent non-disclosure.

The questions about non-disclosure which require investigation in the light of those sorts of provisions would appear to be these: First, whether the existence of the Solomon report was in fact known to some or all of the vendors of the licences; secondly, whether in the terms of the sections I have mentioned, sections 46 and 47 of the existing Acts, any of the vendors of the exploration licences can be said to have been either promoters of the corporation or to have authorised or caused the issuing of this prospectus within the legal meaning of those terms-a difficult interpretation question; thirdly, whether the existence of the negative Solomon report was in fact communicated to any director of the Negri River Corporation Ltd by any of the vendors of the exploration licences or by anyone else, or whether the terms in essence of the Solomon report were known to the directors by some other means. I say that is a point to be resolved while acknowledging again that Sir Davis Hughes at least has denied on behalf of the directors that there was any knowledge by the corporation of the terms of the Solomon report. The final question, of course, which is linked with all of those, is whether in all the circumstances the disclosure or non-disclosure of the Solomon report was in fact material. This is a point that I understand Senator Puplick will make quite vigorously, notwithstanding his own concern about this whole affair. But it remains very much a matter of judgment and a matter to be resolved as to whether in the light of subsequent developments and subsequent geological reports the Solomon report was significant. I simply acknowledge that that is a consideration that has to be resolved rather than simply assumed.

The second kind of legal issue that arises is that related to insider trading. Here again the issues are not simple but they can be stated, I think, fairly briefly. The uniform securities industry Acts of 1975 contain in section 112 a basic prohibition against insider trading. Sub-section (1) of that section provides that a person who is, or at any time in the preceding six months has been, connected with a body corporate shall not deal in securities of that body corporate if by reason of his so being, or having been, connected with that body corporate he is in possession of information that is not generally available but if it were would be likely materially to affect the price of those securities. It seems on the face of it that the existence and contents of the Solomon report would have been likely materially to have affected the price of the Negri shares. That is a question that is a matter of judgment. It may be that investors were so feverish in their inclination to get into this particular market that they would not have been deterred by anything on paper from reputable geologists such as Dr Solomon or from anyone else, but it is difficult in the abstract to argue that it was of no material significance at all. It appears likely, however, even if one accepts that, that the licence vendors, who are alleged to have been in possession of the information in the Solomon report and who did themselves trade, perhaps profitably, in Negri shares thereafter, although being 'connected' with the company within the definition in section 112 (8), did not come into possession of that information 'by reason of' being connected with the company.

It is possible that there is a loophole there in the sense of the non-application of the section to such people. That is an important point which I am making because if it is the case that there is a loophole here or a gap there, it would appear that the alleged circumstances of this case have revealed a significant gap in the insider trading provisions of the legislation. It does seem quite unconscionable that individuals could sell exploration licences, which for the sake of argument let us say are worthless and, having failed to disclose the existence of relevant geological reports, allow an incomplete prospectus to be issued and, having acquired shares in a pre-issue allotment, sell those shares at a price which, by reason of their non-disclosure, is unrealistically high.

I make the point that this is one of the matters in which it is strongly argued that there is a gap in the legislation and one which a committee-preferably the one to which I would like to refer all this-should address its attention. I note that the new national securities industry legislation is couched in terms identical to these pre-existing uniform securities industry Acts which I have mentioned, the relevant provision being section 128. A further provision which I will mention more briefly is contained in section 111 of the existing uniform securities industry Acts, now section 126 of the 1980 national Act which criminally penalises a person who, by any dishonest concealment of material facts, induces or attempts to induce another person to deal in securities. I simply make the point that it may prove on investigation that there was here a deliberate concealment of the Solomon report by the vendors of the licences which had the effect of inducing other persons to deal in the Negri shares.
So, there are a variety of legal issues as to the extent to which the existing law covers the kind of situation which, on the information publicly available at the moment, may well have existed.

In addition, there is another quite substantial issue to be resolved as to the Stock Exchange listing requirements and the extent to which they were observed in this case. Section 2B (11) of the Australian Associated Stock Exchanges' official listing requirements states that a mining company prospectus must, where the company has acquired an interest in an exploration licence, include several requirements, namely, a disclosure of the purchase price paid for the interest and all other consideration including the right to subscribe for the shares offered by the prospectus. Again, there is a requirement that there be a detailed analysis of the purchase price paid by the company for interest in the exploration showing how the price was arrived at and whether or not the company had recourse to expert reports before the purchase price was set and, if so, setting out a summary of those reports. When one looks at the listing requirements by reference to what is actually in the Negri prospectus, all sorts of questions very quickly spring to mind. The third of the listing requirements which is crucial to this argument is that there has to be a statement by the directors as to whether, to their knowledge, the mining tenement has previously been prospected or developed. If so, a summary of the result of that prospecting and so on shall be set out, together with full details of the persons by whom it was conducted. The Negri prospectus does not reveal the fact that the persons allotted shares prior to the public issue were the same persons who had sold the exploration licences to the company and, under the Stock Exchange listing requirements, it should have been investigated whether part of the arrangement for the sale of those licences was that the vendors be allotted shares in that way. If that was part of the consideration for the sale of licences to that company that should have been disclosed in the prospectus in a way that there has been no such disclosure at the moment.

It is also obvious-this is a further important point-that the company is obliged to set out a summary of all expert reports to which it had access and knowledge of the results of previous prospecting. In this respect, as I have already mentioned in passing, the Negri prospectus is deficient to the extent that it excludes any reference to the Solomon report. There is, on page 16 of the prospectus, a fairly detailed list of prior exploratory activity both on the lease area and in nearby leases by a variety of ventures, it being indicated in each case that there had been a failure to find a significant geological prospect. Subsequent to the granting of the licences or in respect of that period there is a list of further geological dabbling and investigation that has been carried out by various people, but again, no reference is made specifically or even, it seems, indirectly, to the Solomon report other than a passing reference to the establishment of an on-site exploration camp during the 1979 dry season and the processing of small quantities of alluvial material utilised in the mobile treatment plant. That may or may not be a reference to the surveying that was carried out by the Solomon team. The reference to previous activity on the site by the leaseholders or by persons associated with them is dismissed in these lines:

The work was of a preliminary nature and was not carried out by qualified personnel. Such work was intended as a guide for the formulation of exploration programs for future years. The results of such work are accordingly considered to be insufficiently verified for inclusion in this prospectus.

So, the impression is given in that prospectus that the only surveying of the licence area-the only prospecting, the only exploration-that has previously been conducted is utterly negligible and utterly inconclusive. So, there is clearly scope for investigation of whether those aspects of the listing requirements have been complied with and, if they have not been complied with, about the failure, it appears, of the Sydney Stock Exchange to take precise and effective remedial action after it came to its attention that there were these deficiencies, for example, to suspend the shares from trading. An ancillary question is, of course, the accuracy and significance of Mr Beith's account that he was told by a senior member of the Melbourne Exchange, in the language I have previously mentioned, to take his money and run. So, the activities of the Stock Exchange, the activities of the Corporate Affairs Commission for its inactivity, if such it was, in taking action on this matter when the existence of the Solomon report was brought to its attention and the inadequacies in various areas of the law, if such they be, all seem clearly to require detailed analysis and investigation. There are many points of analogy with findings of the Rae Committee which, were I not rather testing the patience of the Senate, I would be happy to mention also specifically because the way in which extracts from the Rae report leap out of the page and strike one as having an immediately pertinent and relevant application to the kinds of matters to which I have drawn attention is very graphic.

I believe that an overwhelming case can thus be made out for the Senate's taking this whole issue seriously and treating it to a proper committee investigation. The only questions which then seem to be left are which committee and when? My initial intention in this respect was to seek the re-establishment of a select committee of this Senate to pick up, in effect, where the Rae Select Committee left off. I was persuaded against this on the basis that the standing committees of this Senate are now well established and have a proper role in the following-up of investigations of the kind that were previously conducted by select committees and that it is a more expeditious, less administratively cumbrous sort of arrangement and very much within the charter of the standing committees. I was further persuaded on this basis that the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs was the most appropriate committee, and I have moved accordingly. But it now appears that a majority of the members of that Committee have decided either that it is an inappropriate committee, or that it is an inappropriate time at which to be moving a motion of this kind because of likely changes in the personnel of the Committee, or perhaps because the issue is too big to handle, or that it is too hot to handle. But, for one or other of those reasons, it appears that a view has been taken that this is not a matter for appropriate reference to this Committee or, indeed, it seems any other committee of the Senate at this time.

I acknowledge this: If the real argument is that the issue is currently at least being dealt with by the New South Wales Corporate Affairs Commission and that the consideration of this issue by the Senate should be deferred pending the outcome and public disclosure of the results of that investigation, then I can at least understand that argument. And I can, I suppose, with reasonably good grace accept that, although with a great deal of reluctance because I believe simply that the issues that I have put on the record as needing attention are much wider than those which are presently occupying the Corporate Affairs Commission. But, if we reject my motion, I hope we are not doing so simply because we prefer a quiet life. I hope that it is not because in the Senate we prefer the approach of pottering away, hacking out the odd weed when what is required is a fundamental reshaping of the whole landscape. There is not much good in pulling out little weeds when one is about to be engulfed by a volcano.
Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans has moved that matters relating to the Negri River Corporation Ltd be referred to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. As the Chairman of that Committee I wish to respond to the motion and say something about the matter. Senator Evans has outlined at some length facts and allegations and of course a mixture of facts and allegations in regard to Negri River Corporation Ltd such as the float and other details about which we have heard. I do not propose to go in great detail into the allegations. Senator Puplick will also be speaking to this motion and he will deal with the matters in more detail. He is more familiar with the controversy that has raged now for some months in regard to this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The motion proposes that the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee inquire into and report on a number of matters. If one looks at the proposed inquiry one is immediately faced with the fact that what is suggested is a very extensive inquiry which undoubtedly would be a very controversial inquiry, which would involve people's reputations and which no doubt would involve a good deal of investigation and careful consideration by any committee. The matters which are raised in the terms of the motion cover, as I have suggested, a very wide ambit. The proposed reference concerns not only the floating of the company and the way in which it came about but also the adequacy of the prospectus and the question of whether there were geological reports that were disclosed or known by people who gained a benefit from the company. Another question is the role of the Sydney Stock Exchange in relation to listing, together with, as has been put by Senator Evans, the question of insider trading. The proposed inquiry moves from that to a very extensive inquiry into not only the problems which in the past had been considered by the Rae Committee and not only the question of whether these problems have been overcome by the existing legislation but also the adequacy of the operations of the State corporate affairs commissions and the proposed Federal legislation. This is an intimidating list of requirements for a committee to investigate and a list with which one can say without question that probably no committees of this Senate with their knowledge at the moment are particularly qualified to deal at present.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying 'not qualified'?

—Are not particularly qualified to deal with at this time. I do not for one moment maintain that members of my Committee have particular knowledge in the area of company law or that it has in fact made any investigation in this area whatsoever. As in all things, there must be a start; someone must go first. On the other hand it can be said that in this area my Committee can claim no particular expertise whatsoever. I do not relate the facts; I do not go into the facts. The matters which have been raised by Senator Evans seem to me on the whole to be a pretty admirable assessment of the course of events. On the other hand, some of the matters he has referred to relate to allegations that have been made and they would of course be the subject of testing by evidence. There is no doubt that in the course of that testing persons whose reputations would be involved would require counsel, the committee would require counsel-a great deal of expert advice-and there would be a very thorough defence by anyone against whom allegations have been made. Senator Evans may say that there is scope for investigation, and I do not doubt that. At the same time it must be said that any such investigation would be a very extensive and long ranging one if justice were to be done.

SPEECH.PARA: This brings me to the fact that the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee has had the opportunity since Senator Evans gave notice of this motion last Thursday to consider the proposed reference. Members of the Committee decided, with Senator Evans dissenting, that such a reference should not be given to the Committee at this time and accordingly I, and I think other members of the Committee, will be opposed to the motion at this time. We do not as a Committee say that there should not be a case for later investigation. We certainly do not say that there may not be suspicious circumstances and matters which are of a good deal of concern to the community arising from the allegations.

Undoubtedly one fact which should be borne in mind at the moment is that the New South Wales Corporate Affairs Commission is investigating as a special investigation the matters that Senator Evans has raised. It may well be said that some of the activities of that Commission may be the subject of some criticism. One will not know until that Commission reports whether in fact it can provide an adequate explanation of the situation and satisfy the public that the matters raised are above board and that no action should be taken. On the other hand, it may recommend the prosecution of persons. One cannot tell at this stage. It is the belief of our Committee that it would not be wise for an investigation to be undertaken by a Senate committee at the same time as the New South Wales Corporate Affairs Commission is proceeding with an investigation. Until that investigation is completed, in my opinion, no committee of this kind ought to engage in such an investigation. It is primarily for this reason that the Committee has recommended to the Senate that such a reference be not given to it at this time. It may well be that after the report of the New South Wales Commission is made some investigation will be taken.

There is no doubt that this Parliament is still very responsible for ensuring that the law as now proposed and the new arrangements for corporate affairs cover the problems which have been raised and rightly so by Senator Evans. It may well be that further investigations should be made in that area, but that may be an area of interest to some committee other than the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee, which as I have said has made no previous investigations in this area and has not previously been concerned in corporate affairs or in the legislation that is involved in this subject. But that is a matter for further investigation.

All the areas that have been raised by Senator Evans are, I think, important ones. Those areas include the question of whether there was non-disclosure in regard to the geological reports of Dr Solomon, insider trading, possible deficiencies in company law and whether they have been corrected by the existing legislation, whether the State corporate affairs commissions are operating effectively and whether the umbrella of the new National Companies and Securities Commission is an adequate way of handling corporate affairs. All these matters are matters of which this Parliament must have continual cognisance. I do not for one moment say that that is not something that ought not to be investigated. I doubt that immediately is the time, as we are still in the process of bringing the law into operation, and certainly there should not be an inquiry by us before the New South Wales Corporate Affairs Commission has reported on the facts of this case.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would commend Senator Evans for raising it here as a matter of national importance, though?

—Yes. Senator Evans raised this matter early in December, I think, and he has again raised it. I in no way criticise him. I would have liked him to have approached the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee before he moved his motion. I think that would have been more helpful to our Committee, but I raise no particular objection.
—I approached the key members of it on your side, with respect.

—Yes, I make it perfectly clear that Senator Evans had spoken to a number of members-I do not know about key members-including myself and Senator Puplick. He had, in fact, mentioned that he was interested in this matter. There was nothing like subterfuge or inadequacy of discussion by Senator Evans in that sense but, unfortunately, the matter was not discussed with the Committee until after the notice of motion had been given. I make that point as a minor point. The Committee has had the opportunity since that time to consider the matter, to hear Senator Evans at length, to discuss this matter at length yesterday and to make the decision which it has made. The Committee has current work. It has a report nearing completion in regard to the qualifications and disqualifications of members. It has another reference which it is to embark upon and on which it has already sought evidence.
—It is of national importance.

—No, I am not saying that it is of national importance but it is a useful reference given to it by this Parliament which it should consider as a duty to this Parliament. It is a reference which is useful and in which the people to whom we have written have expressed great interest.
—Senator Tate is very keen on it.

—Senator Tate, a good member of the Committee, is indeed interested in it. At least two, or possibly more, members of the Committee will soon cease to hold office. Two members are leaving the Parliament in June.
—Who make up the present personnel of the Committee?
—The present personnel from the Australian Labor Party are Senator Evans, Senator Tate and Senator Wheeldon. Senator Wheeldon is leaving the Parliament.
—He has made a great contribution. He will be missed.

—Yes, indeed. The Government component comprises myself, Senator Puplick and Senator Hamer. As I was saying, possibly half of the Committee members will cease to hold office and there will be a changeover of personnel in the middle of the year. It is undesirable for the Committee to take on a reference of length and complexity at a time when there will be changes in its composition and while it is still proceeding to deal with a matter. I will not go further into this matter.
—Very wise.

—I do not maintain that I know a great deal about the details. I have read material about this matter that has appeared publicly and which has been referred to by Senator Evans. I do not draw conclusions. I think it may well be that the Senate, through a committee or some other means, will have to do something in respect of this matter and will have to make some inquiries about it. But it would be a mistake if the Senate were to undertake an investigation which would cut across an existing investigation. It would be a mistake if the reference were given to a committee which would then have to change its complexion, in the form of the people who constitute it, in midstream. For the various reasons I have given I think it would be undesirable for this inquiry to be undertaken in the form in which Senator Evans proposes. For these reasons I oppose the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —As both Senator Evans and Senator Missen have indicated, I propose to deal with some of the substance of this discussion on the Negri River Corporation Ltd in more depth than has my colleague, Senator Missen, and as somebody who had made an attempt to follow not only the progress of this matter but also the progress of a number of companies, corporations and organisations which have been involved in what one might loosely call the diamond exploration boom which has taken place over the course of the last two years or so. I would not want to traverse the same details to which Senator Missen has referred. The reasons that the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs at its meeting yesterday in Melbourne found persuasive in terms of not accepting this matter as a committee reference relate to reasons regarding the amount of time, the resources, the personnel and other factors already canvassed by Senator Missen.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I would simply stress the point which was central to Senator Missen's contribution; namely, that at least two inquiries are currently under way into this matter, one being undertaken by the Corporate Affairs Commission of New South Wales and the other being undertaken by the Sydney Stock Exchange. It is perfectly true that both of these organisations may have questions to answer as to their own participation in the whole scheme of arrangements. The persuasive view that I think was accepted by the Committee was that at least until the Corporate Affairs Commission report is presented it would be unwise to embark on either a duplication or an attempt to second guess a report which presumably in a fairly short period will become a public document.

I therefore propose to deal with a number of matters that have already been raised by Senator Evans and to add, I hope, some further details about these allegations and some of these related reports. I wish to start by putting the matter into an historical perspective as far as the activities of the diamond miners in both Western Australia and the Northern Territory are concerned. As far back as 13 June 1978 the Australian Financial Review carried an article headed 'The Scramble for Diamonds in WA'. Its sub-heading was 'Son of Poseidon'. Those familiar with activities in the nickel boom, with the activities of Poseidon and with everything which that entailed will understand that this was a clear warning given as far back as 13 June 1978 that here was an area of resource development in which one could expect a degree of speculation, a fair amount of high flying and, indeed, a large amount of risk being taken all round the place.

The London Financial Times of 5 September 1978 was also anxious to put this matter into perspective. It started running stories about the Ashton consortium's exploration for diamonds in Western Australia. It quoted a remark by Sir Roderick Carnegie who, on behalf of Conzinc Rio Tinto of Australia Ltd-one of the principal partners in the Ashton consortium-was asked what he thought about the eventual outcome of the Ashton activities. Sir Roderick, as reported in the London Financial Times, said:
Ask me after another five years and $15m.

To a large extent at least the five years have not passed but the $15m is certainly starting to look like a progressively attainable target for expenditure on activities in that part of the world. The Financial Times on that occasion went on to say:

Stockbrokers are reminded of the past. It seemed inconceivable that people who had been so shaken by the Poseidon boom-and-bust seven years ago would, so soon afterwards, once again be swept to a renewed enthusiasm. Only the terminology, of course, has changed. The jargon now is of diamoniferous kimberlites, of indicator minerals-meaning pyrope garnite and pierotlmenite-that turn an ordinary volcanic plug into a kimberlite with the potential for carrying diamonds.
The article continued:

The basic pattern is nothing new: a commodity is found in a remote area. The more exotic the commodity, the more esoteric its technology, and the more remote from civilisation the pegging, the greater the area of uncertainty, and the greater the element of speculation.

I think that encapsulates the sort of framework which people in both the stock market and the financial Press have traded on and, that is, that there is something terribly alluring about this particular resource development. I raised the matter first in the Senate on 17 November 1978 when talking about the current Ashton explorations. I tried to indicate that I believed that many people would get their fingers burnt in this exercise for those very reasons-that the speculation, the allure, the magic word 'diamond' and all the rest of it would combine to bring about a situation in which people would be tempted to invest their money in what they hoped would be an overnight get rich quick scheme. The Bulletin and Newsweek magazines by featuring cover stories on the diamond boom and saying that people should invest their money in diamonds as a hedge against inflation were simply adding to the whole situation.

In May and June of 1978 Graham Beith, to whom we shall return on a couple of occasions, sought and obtained maps and reports from the Department of Mines and Energy in Darwin covering the areas known as Limbunya and Waterloo near Mistake Creek and near the junction of that creek with the Negri River. He, according to his own testimony to people, was prompted to look in that area by stories of a diamond which had turned up in Tennant Creek where it had been sold to a local jeweller by an Aboriginal who thought it was a sapphire. Mr Beith, tracking down this elusive diamond, had managed to find the Aboriginal concerned; he managed to track him back to a situation in which he obtained information that this sapphire, which in fact was a diamond, had been found by the Aboriginal near Mistake Creek. Mr Beith obtained rights over what are known as exploration licence areas 2092 and 2093 in partnership with Mr Campbell Cooper, a well-known prospector and one who established his reputation at the very height of the Poseidon nickel boom by managing to peg the right places at the right time, and Mr David Lance who, as Senator Evans has said, is a stockbroker associated with the firm of Norths in Sydney.

After a while, in order to obtain some further information about the area contained within ELs 2092 and 2093, Mr Beith, together with Mr Frank Nugan, commissioned a report from a well-known and reputed Sydney geologist, Dr Peter Solomon. I do not propose to speculate on Mr Nugan's involvement in his matter. I do not think anybody would be able to ascertain at this stage exactly what it was, how it was, what motivated it or anything about it. It would simply be one of those curious and interesting alleys down which, undoubtedly, any Senate investigation would wander for a little while before presumably coming upon either the same blank walls as have been encountered by most investigations of the activities of Mr Nugan or some wild allegation that, in fact, Negri River is one of the continuing alleged Central Intelligence Agency plots for undermining something or other in Australia.

Anyway, Beith and Nugan commissioned Dr Solomon to undertake his investigation. Dr Solomon's report which is dated 25 July 1979 was cautious but essentially negative. Dr Solomon, in the first part of his report which runs only to some two and a half pages, indicated that he had found no minerals of economic significance in the area. He believed that further work in the area was unwarranted, and he recommended that exploration licence applications 2092, 2093, 2120 and 2121 be withdrawn immediately.

It ought to be said of Dr Solomon's report that he was not on the ground for a particularly long period. It also ought to be said that included within the framework of Dr Solomon's report there is not a detailed study of the Landsat photographs covering that area. I mention that because those Landsat photographs become of some relevance when one progresses to the next major geological report on the area. I think it is also of significance to know that Mr Beith communicated with a solicitor in a letter dated 7 December 1979, a letter addressed to Mr T. G. Peken, Esquire of Higgins, Morgan and Partners, Temple Court, Elizabeth Street, Sydney. Mr Beith in his letter to this solicitor said:

I emphasise at this point that Solomon did not attempt a sampling at any point West of 129 degrees East, and that at best, his work, because of the financial limitations placed on him, was perfunctory.

It is, I think, important to understand that Mr Beith who is one of the two persons who commissioned the report subsequently described the report as being-his word-'perfunctory'. That leads us later to certain judgmental values to which I shall refer.

The next thing I want to say about negative geological reports, particularly as they affect diamond mining, is as follow: First, not all negative reports mean that one should put away any hope that prospects exist. The famous story that goes around the geological circles is of the very distinguished geologist who, in 1947, said that he would drink all the oil that was found in Alberta which now bases its economy upon its extensive discoveries of oil; secondly, it should be noted that all published geological maps of Western Australia failed to show kimberlite bodies where they have subsequently been found; thirdly, it should be indicated that indeed very extensive field work in areas now known and proved to contain kimberlites prior to their actual discovery on the ground did not record the presence of kimberlites; that is to say, of areas bearing diamond deposits.

The two important events that occurred after the following report, however, are these: First, in late 1979 the Ashton partners, exploring on their Argyle leases which are about 100 kilometres removed from the area which we are discussing, the Negri River, made major discoveries of kimberlites and, indeed, of diamonds. In fact, the most recent work on this, published by Leo Chapman, the book entitled Diamonds in Australia: The Fields and the Prospectors was published last year by Bay Books in Sydney, and says:

Late in 1979, the Ashton Joint Venture made a major discovery of alluvial diamond beds and a kimberlite pipe near Lake Argyle close to the Ord River Dam and the cattle port of Wyndham in the Kimberley region. CRA termed the find 'a new diamond province'. The alluvial diamonds were found on Smoke Creek 120 kilometres from the Argyle pipe. The biggest stone recovered before the onset of the wet season was 7.03 carats, found in the Smoke Creek alluvials.
The book then goes on to discuss another Ashton exploration at Ellendale. It states:
Ellendale is problematical, but a strong point in its favour is the high proportion of gem diamonds found in tests so far.

I do not want to weary the Senate with precise geological explanations of this but it is interesting to note that the bases of the Ashton discoveries have been not only diamonds in kimberlite formation but also diamonds in alluvial deposits. The Negri River system is part of the same river system-in other words, part of the same alluvial system-as the deposits so far encountered in other branches of the Ord River system by Ashtons and by others.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is way upstream. It is not downstream from those other discoveries.

—The way in which the river flows at the moment is not necessarily relevant to the way in which the river system may have been flowing at the time when the riverbed sank, leaving the alluvial diamond deposits along its entire course to be either found or exposed at a later date. It is important that they be part of the same river system. The fact that we may be talking about what happened 10,000, 20,000 or 30,000 years back in terms of the alluvial nature of the region does not necessarily mean simply that because things are in upstream and downstream relationship to each other at the moment in fact that was the case at the time when those alluvial deposits were laid down.
—The rivers were all flowing inland 20,000 years ago, were they?

—If Senator Evans is capable of speculating about what was the case 10,000 to 20,000 years ago I would be happy to defer to his expert judgment in the matter. If it is in the platform of the Australian Labor Party that the rivers flow in a particular direction then I am sure they do.

SPEECH.PARA: The second event that has occurred since the Solomon report came into existence is that the partners concerned in the Negri River exercise have commissioned a geologist, Dr Alan H. Voisey, a former Professor of Geology at Macquarie University and about whose bona fides Senator Evans has already spoken this evening, to undertake an investigation. I guess that his investigation could be described as perfunctory in some respects. He certainly studied the Landsat photographs of the area, unlike Dr Solomon, and spent some time, not a great deal of time I agree, on the ground in the particular area. His report dated 10 October 1980, is contained on pages 6 and 7 of the Negri prospectus, and draws a couple of matters to our attention. The report states:

In the latter part of 1979, an announcement was made of the discovery of diamonds in two distinct geological environments in a portion of the Ord River catchment, upstream from Lake Argyle, in the northeast of Western Australia . . . The environments constituted a diamondiferous kimberlite pipe and, in the major drainage system downstream from the pipe, extensive diamond-bearing alluvial gravels.
His recommendation was as follows:

Because of the announced discovery of kimberlite and diamonds near Lake Argyle, it would be fair to say that the country and the gravel deposits covered by the Ord River catchment have been upgraded as diamond prospects. I recommend that Negri River Corporation Limited, having regard to the presence within the Licence Area of extensive alluvial deposits and of major structural features which could have provided channelways for kimberlite emplacement, should commence a detailed exploration programme on the Licence Area.

Dr Voisey, questioned later about the existence of the Solomon report, is quoted in the Australian Financial Review of 4 December 1980 as saying that even if he had been aware of the Solomon report it would not have caused him to alter the comments which he made and which appeared in the Negri prospectus. The article in the Financial Review states:

Dr Alan Voisey stated yesterday that even if he had seen the report by Dr Peter Solomon recommending immediate abandonment of the Negri areas, it would not have caused him to alter his recommendations to the Negri board that the areas were prospective for diamonds and warranted investigation.

A major judgmental decision for people to make as a result is this: Is the extent to which the 'perfunctory' reports-that is Mr Beith's word-from Dr Solomon had not only been superseded but indeed had also been rendered totally irrelevant by the two new and significant factors, namely, the Argyle discovery and the Voisey report sufficient basis for not including in the prospectus the details, in precise terms, of the Solomon report?

The next substantive group of issues to which I wish to turn concerns various agreements in which Mr Beith was involved, in the period from July 1979 to January 1980. On 25 July 1979 Mr Beith, in a hand-written document, authorised the stockbroker, David Lance, to sell out his interests in ELs 2092 and 2093 for a sum of not less than $2,000. On 8 August 1979 he purported to sell to a Mr S. Griff his interests in those two exploration licence areas for the sum of $2,600.

In November 1979 Mr Beith engaged in some sort of dispute with his former partners, Cooper and Lance with Griff and sent telexes to the Northern Territory Mines Department indicating the existence of some dispute about the ownership or otherwise of the exploration licences. In January 1980 all of these disputes appeared to have been settled one way or the other and on or about 16 or 17 January 1980 Beith finally sold part of his interests in licence areas 2092 and 2093 to Design and Construction Pty Ltd of Mt Isa, a company which is owned by Sir Asher Joel and his family interests.
