One cannot help feeling that Mr Beith has somewhat sold his heritage for a mess of pottage or, having traded the proverbial cow for a couple of beans, he finds that the beans are unlikely to grow.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very easy to discredit him by that sort of statement-the sour grapes syndrome.

—We will come to the credit of Mr Beith in a moment. The Negri prospectus was subsequently issued and, like all prospectuses of this nature, it bears on the front page in fairly bold type a four word disclaimer which simply reads: 'This issue is speculative'. As Senator Evans indicated, it was issued on 15 October 1980 with Negri having four named directors. The directors of that company were Sir Davis Hughes, former leader of the National Country Party in New South Wales, former Minister, and former New South Wales Agent-General in London; Geoffrey Kelvin Gray who would be known to people in Sydney as the principal of G. K. Gray and Co., the auctioneers; Dr Brian Marshall, about whom I must confess I know absolutely nothing, and Michael Murray Hornibrook who is a solicitor of some repute in Sydney. Some honourable senators will know of my interest in greyhound racing. Mr Hornibrook is the solicitor for the National Coursing Association and handles all of its legal work. From my own knowledge, Mr Hornibrook is a solicitor of integrity and a person who would not be associated with any untoward dealings.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, the prospectus included on pages 6 and 7 the full details of the Voisey report. Page 16 of that prospectus also included reference to certain explorations that had taken place in the licence area. In fact, four of them of fairly negative character were indicated in the prospectus-the 1970 Antrim Copper Project Joint Venture, negative results; the 1973 Amoco Minerals Australia, negative results; the 1976 A.O. (Australia) Pty. Ltd., results which the report says were regarded as having negative features, and the 1979 Anaconda Australia Inc. program. The report says Anaconda conducted a reconnaisance program searching for large scale base metal deposits in the Victoria River region but reported that no significant discoveries were made. The matter then hit the popular Press, one might say, once the prospectus was released and on 22 October 1980 the Australian Financial Review led with a story under the heading: 'The Gem Float No One's Shouting About'. I will read part of the article and I will seek to have the whole of it incorporated in Hansard. The report reads, in part, as follows:
The areas cover the south-eastern part of the Ord River catchment, up-river from Lake Argyle and abutting the Northern Territory border.
In other words, they represent Northern Territory equivalents of the areas where the CRA group has outlined its extensive Argyle deposits.
But the prospectus practically tries to not sell the shares on offer.

Apart from the comment by the company's consulting geologist, that because of the Argyle discoveries 'it would be fair to say the country and the gravel deposits covered by the Ord River catchment have been upgraded as diamond prospects', there is no speculative invitation discernible in the prospectus.
I quote again a paragraph in the Australian Financial Review report:
But the prospectus practically tries to not sell the shares on offer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would it have been written that way if the author had known that the promoters were sitting on a negative geological report?

—Senator, I am not aware how Mr Mills, who apparently is the author concerned, would or would not have written his report. I simply say that that is his description of the prospectus as it appeared to him and as it was issued. I seek leave to incorporate the article in the Australian Financial Review in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
THE GEM FLOAT NO ONE'S SHOUTING ABOUT
By Bob Mills Country Party NSW
THE Sydney stockbroker Norths is one of the more careful and older-established firms working out of Bond St, which makes its association with a diamond exploration float unusual.

When the vendors of the diamond property are Cam Cooper, who made himself famous by pegging the mining warden's court in Leonora during Poseidon days, Sir Asher Joel, who is best known as director of Sydney Festivals and a media entrepreneur, and one of Norths' own consultants, the idea begins to sound unlikely.

Perhaps this is why Norths has approached the market to offer 3.5 million fully paid 20c shares in Negri River Corp Ltd, with a property that less circumspect members of the broking fraternity would regard as red hot, so quietly that almost no one has noticed.
The Negri float is to raise funds to carry out initial exploration on very extensive alluvial flats included in the 2,452 square kilometres of two licence areas being put into Negri.
The areas cover the south-eastern part of the Ord River catchment, up-river from Lake Argyle and abutting the Northern Territory border.
In other words, they represent Northern Territory equivalents of the areas where the CRA group has outlined its extensive Argyle deposits.
But the prospectus practically tries to not sell the shares on offer.

Apart from the comment by the company's consulting geologist, that because of the Argyle discoveries 'it would be fair to say the country and the gravel deposits covered by the Ord River catchment have been upgraded as diamond prospects', there is no speculative invitation discernible in the prospective.
The promoters of the float have gone to extreme lengths to achieve a near impossibility, in making a highly speculative mining prospectus read respectably.
Not only are Norths the underwriters, but Laing and Cruickshank, one of the big 10 of the London Stock Exchange, are London brokers to the issue.

Given the eagerness shown by local investors for recent diamond exploration raisings, attracting a London broker may seem a redundant touch for an issue which only seeks to raise $700,000, but the name is an impressive inclusion.

So are the names of the officials of the company. Sir Davis Hughes, former leader of the NSW Country Party and Agent-General in London is chairman, Geoffrey K. Gray the auctioneer, is deputy chairman, and the other directors are Dr Brian Marshall, who has a reputation in geological circles, and Michael Hornibrook.
The understated geological report included in the prospectus is signed by Professor Alan Voisey, the company's consulting geologist.

Then there is the news that the vendors of the area are actually subscribing for their interest in the company, through a prior issue of 3.5 million shares also at 20c each, and will immediately get out of it only $90,000 to cover part of their expenses to date on the areas.

The vendors' interest is even more highly speculative than most as it is not particularly marketable, consisting of a 12 per cent royalty on net profits from any mining operation that results up to a maximum of $12 million.

According to David Lance, one of the vendors and head of the research department at Norths, the other extraordinary aspect of the float is that the vendors came by their property before Lake Argyle became the most fashionable diamond address in Australia.
The licences were applied for in April, 1979, before CRA announced its Lake Argyle results, and before CRA started pegging all the alluvial country in sight.
This is why such an obscure consortium is sitting on land surrounded by areas held by the big names in diamond exploration, including CRA, Western Mining Corporation and CSR.
The vendors, finally, secured the areas after following up consistent rumours, from an English school teacher and Aborigines, of diamonds in the area.

Several companies including Antrim Copper, Amoco Minerals Australia, A.O. Australia and Anaconda Australia have been through the areas, mostly looking for copper or large-scale base metals deposits, and have come up empty handed.

So far the licence holders have managed a limited program of work, including basic geological outlining, but as they say in the prospectus 'the work was of a preliminary nature and was not carried out by qualified personnel. Such work was intended as a guide for the formulation of exploration programs for future years. The results of such work are accordingly considered to be insufficiently verified for inclusion in this prospectus'.

TALK.START.PARA: —The important matter was, quite clearly, that things took off from this point. On 14 November the New South Wales Corporate Affairs Commission sought from Lane and Lane, the solicitors for Sir Asher Joel and others, a copy of the Solomon report which the Corporate Affairs Commission by that stage had reason to believe was in their possession. On 17 November that report was delivered to the Corporate Affairs Commission of New South Wales.
—By Lane?
—I believe so, by the solicitors, yes.
—By Lane and Lane?
—Yes, Senator, I believe so, by Lane and Lane.
—They do have it in their possession.
—That is correct, Senator. They were requested by the Corporate Affairs Commission to provide the report. They did so.
—That does not demonstrate to me that they had it in their keeping.

—Indeed, it may well have been in the possession of their client as distinct from being in their possession. All I say is that the request was made by the CAC to the solicitors. The solicitors provided the report, but where they obtained it I am not in a position to say.
—There is nothing inconsistent with Beith's story that he gave it to them in December 1979.

—There does not necessarily appear to be any inconsistency on the face of it, Senator Evans. The float did not really open for public subscription on the market until 20 November. Then, quite clearly, the 20c shares took off at a great pace. They briefly hit the $2 mark. Certainly there was a lot of activity by what are known as stags on the market taking full advantage of the boom in the price.

SPEECH.PARA: The point I want to make is that for a period of some days prior to the float opening on the Exchange in Sydney the Corporate Affairs Commission of New South Wales was in possession not only of the prospectus but also of the Solomon report and the Commission, charged as it is with the responsibility to oversee matters of company legislation and behaviour in New South Wales, did not seek to intervene in that period. There are a number of possible explanations as to why that occurred. Quite clearly it may have been, indeed I believe, that it made proper judgment that there was no basis to intervene. It may have been as has been suggested that the Commission was simply negligent or indeed that somebody was paid off. There are a number of possible explanations, but they do not detract from the fact that the Solomon report was in the Commission's possession.

A number of things, of course, were occurring at the same time. On 4 December 1980 the general atmosphere of the market was good for diamonds. On 4 December 1980 the Sydney Morning Herald led with the headline 'Ashton's 13 carat stone . . .' The story read:
A 13-carat diamond-the largest so far found in the Kimberley search-has been recovered by the Ashton joint venture in its exploration of the Smoke Creek area near Lake Argyle.

Even Senator Evans's speech on 5 December did not dampen this market because on 8 December the Australian Financial Review led with the heading 'Ashton's Smoke Creek diamonds ''worth $53m''.' The article stated:
Ashton mining NL has estimated reserves at its Upper Smoke Creek deposits-
I interpolate that that is part of the same river system--
At about four million carats of diamonds worth about $53m.

The atmosphere was pretty good for people getting in on what they thought may well have been a speculative issue. As I said, Senator Evans spoke on 5 December and his speech received fairly wide Press publicity despite the fact that he said-I think I can recall his speech-that certain things had not been included in the prospectus. Some members of the Press chose to write this up by saying that certain things had been omitted from the prospectus. Perhaps those words have the same meaning; I would not have thought so. Senator Evans was certainly careful to say that things had not been included but most reports exaggerated it in quite an improper fashion by saying that things had been omitted.

The debate in which the honourable senator was engaged-during the course of it I made some interjections-also raised the extent to which Mr Beith had sought to provide to parties the Solomon report, with certain conditions attached, at the cost of $10,000. I think it is important to understand within the context of the whole situation that Mr Beith was acting not quite the white knight in shining armour role but was prepared to sell a report which he presumably had in his possession for $10,000. Next, the Australian Financial Review drew attention to the speculation in Negri affairs with a report, including a picture of Sir Asher Joel, which appeared on 12 December. The article was headed 'Negri vendor's staggering profits'.
The article went on to state:
A company associated with Sir Asher Joel and his family has sold its entire shareholding in Negri River Corporation Ltd for a gross profit of $1.36 million.

Now, that if anything, is one of the most damaging indictments that one could find of the way in which the financial Press operates in Australia. It is one of the sloppiest pieces of reporting that one could possibly find. If one looks at what happened on that first day of trading it will be found, indeed, that the Bulletin, which got into the act on 23 December, wrote as follows:
Certain sections of the Press are running a campaign of harassment against Sir Asher Joel, one of the vendors to the Negri River Corporation diamond prospecting float.
The article went on to discuss the way in which the Australian Financial Review had alleged that the Joel family had made $1.36m. The Bulletin article further stated:
The company, Lindfield Enterprises Pty Ltd-
Which I interpolate is a Joel family company--

owned 1,040,000 Negri shares when that company listed on November 20. Shortly afterwards the shares were dispersed to four other companies, including Morrisons Outdoor Catering Pty Ltd (100,000 shares) and Tilliana Pty Ltd (924,998 shares).
The article further stated:

The Financial Review's breathless expose said: 'Tilliana's registered office is c/- Coopers and Lybrand, chartered accountants, of Mt Isa, but the identity of the shareholder or directors of the purchasing company remains a mystery'.
Any mug should know-and particularly a finance reporter-that Mt Isa is one of the centres of the Joel family's operations, where they publish the daily newspaper and the national Mining Newspaper.

In fact the Joel family control both Morrisons Outdoor Catering and Tilliana-so far from selling out, they are still very much committed shareholders, and their 'staggering profits' are very much a paper exercise.

As I said, this exposes the weakness of financial journalism in this country because, in fact, Morrisons Outdoor Catering Pty Ltd is not one of the companies owned by the Asher Joel interests. The Bulletin in its 'Wildcat' column on 16 December 1980 tried to put the matter into some perspective with the heading 'Negri hysteria.'

It indicated, as I have done, that the Solomon report had largely been overtaken by the Asian discovery and by the Voisey report. It indicated that AOG consultants-AOG is one of the mining explorers in the area-had recommended the surrounding areas as areas where leases should be taken out and that they had been advised by Geoffrey Nannes who has 29 years' experience in Australia and Africa and Dr Bruce Walpole, who has 30 years' experience, including 15 years at the Bureau of Mineral Resources. It was indicated that a large number of people in that area were still taking leases over related areas because they believed that it was, in fact, a good prospect. Indeed they continue to do so. De Beers is interested and only yesterday Diamond Mines of Australia announced a float for its leases on the Lennard River. On 2 December 1980 the Sydney Stock Exchange had decided that it would undertake some investigation and that the Chairman of the Stock Exchange, Mr Mullens, said that the executive committee had already examined the Negri River situation and had decided that there would be no suspension of trading in Negri shares at that stage.

The next point I wish to make-honourable senators will be pleased to know that we are coming towards the end of this saga-is that on 24 February 1981 Mr John Brown, a member in the other place, made a speech on the National Companies and Security Commission Amendment Bill in which he made reference to this matter. It is important because he raised the position of Graham Beith once again. Earlier today Senator Evans described Mr Beith. I think his words were that he was a 'central character' in the whole of this exercise. Mr John Brown indicated that Beith was allotted 15,000 shares in the float but to use Mr John Brown's words ' . . . to his eternal credit he refused to trade in them.'

Senator Evans made reference to Mr Beith in terms of what Mr Beith is alleged to have said to Sir Asher Joel and what his alleged understanding was with Sir Asher Joel about the extent to which the Solomon report would-to quote Senator Evans again-'figure prominently' in public statements about this mater. Mr Beith is a former employee of the Joel family interests. He was employed in Mount Isa and later in Sydney on the Australian Miner, a newspaper which is owned and operated by the Joel family interests. It is unfortunate that the question of Mr Beith's position has to be taken into account and examined closely.

I do not think Mr Beith is a witness of credibility. There are legitimate grounds for Senator Evans being prepared to put a certain weight on his evidence and for me to be prepared to put a certain different weight on his evidence. Mr Beith has a number of outstanding judgments against his name for the non-payment of debts. He is a person who has been in a position that he may well, for one reason or another, have done himself out of a potentially lucrative situation-whether by his own activity, whether he has been deceived by somebody, misled by somebody or whether he has been misinformed by somebody, one does not know. I think it is difficult to establish a pattern of credibility to the evidence of Mr Beith when he was prepared to sell the Solomon report for $10,000 on certain conditions and build that into a central pillar of a case to be made about persons involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —To get his own $10,000 back, for God's sake. You know that was what it was about, and to flush out the report.

—My understanding is that to a very large extent the expenses incurred in the production of the Solomon report were paid by Mr Nugan and not by Mr Beith. Even that sort of point indicates the difficulties that arise. It is certainly true that a large number of public reputations are at stake in this matter. Sir Asher Joel's is only one of them, but his has been the most prominent. Sir Asher is not a particular favourite of many persons. He is not a particular favourite of the Corporate Affairs Commission. I do not think he is a particular favourite of Mr Walker, the Attorney-General in New South Wales. The fact that he was such a prominent character witness in the trial of Mr Ian Sinclair might make people form judgments on that basis. It is important to understand that for a Senate committee to be invited, given the limitations that Senator Missen has described as far as such a committee is concerned, to undertake an investigation into this matter without the time and resources that would be required would be a mistake.
—You seem to have plenty of resources at your disposal. Would you like to communicate some of your sources of information to us?

—My sources of information are ones in which I put sufficient faith, just as Senator Evans's own discussions with the New South Wales Government have put him in a position to have certain judgmental values. I am prepared to have them tested, if tested they need be. I am prepared to accept them as being legitimate and proper. Senator Evans will know that I have taken an interest in this and related matters for some years which might not be said of certain other honourable senators in this place. I am prepared to go on the public record in the way in which I have, having taken the time and trouble to investigate a matter which Senator Evans has thought of sufficient importance in the public interest to bring forward for discussion. Within that framework I am perfectly prepared to make the remarks which I have and to indicate the support which I give to the decision.
—It is a throw-away line about a man's credibility.

—They are facts, Senator. They are on the public record. They stand as they do, and I am prepared to stand by them. As far as the situation which has been debated in the Senate this evening is concerned, I believe the decision should be made on the basis of the recommendation from the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, that this matter should not be referred to that Committee, but that the matter could if necessary, be looked at again when the Corporate Affairs Commission has reported on the public record about the nature of the evidence which it has before it. This course of action which should be followed by the Senate and the recommendation which I support, joined as I am by three of my colleagues on that particular Senate committee, ought to be supported by the Senate and the matter dealt with on that basis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter this debate very briefly to indicate my reasons for being prepared to vote against the acceptance by the Senate Standing Commitee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs of this proposed reference. I do so on a very simple and I think sufficient ground, even though the matter is one of great importance in the community and is of very real concern as Australia begins to marshal its own internal capital resources to participate, as it ought, in the equity required to finance the so-called resources boom. Those concerns and matters of interest do require investigation when there is, as appears from newspaper reports, to which I restrict myself, an apparent instance of the public's not being fully informed on matters which were apparently known to the directors of the Negri River Corporation Ltd float.

SPEECH.PARA: If it were the case that this matter was not under investigation by any competent authority it may well be that the Senate at this stage ought to use one of its committees to commence such an investigation, but the fact is that the matter is under investigation by at least two authorities-one being the Sydney Stock Exchange, which I put to one side, and the other being the New South Wales Corporate Affairs Commission. While that investigation is being conducted by the officers of that Commission, the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs is an inappropriate vehicle to carry out a parallel investigation.

I base my opinion on the ground which I believed Senator Puplick was making at the beginning of his remarks but which he completely undermined in the course of them. I do so on the basis that it is not for the Senate to impugn the integrity or competence of the Corporate Affairs Commission until we have its report before us. Senator Puplick did impugn either the integrity or the competence of the Corporate Affairs Commission. He said that it was either totally incompetent and negligent in not making available the Solomon report which was in its possession or that perhaps somebody had been paid off not to make it available.

TALK.START.PARA: —He gave another alternative.
—Or that it was deliberate.
—Or that it was a legitimate judgment.

—Or that it was a legitimate matter of judgment. In any case, he raised questions as to the integrity and competence of the Commission. I go further than that. He did say that he thought the Corporate Affairs Commission and the New South Wales Attorney-General had a bias against Sir Asher Joel, which to my mind is to impugn the integrity of the investigation being conducted. I do not accept that we should make that sort of impugning of the integrity or competence of the Corporate Affairs Commission until we are in possession of its report. We may then come to the sorts of conclusions that are being hinted at by both Senator Evans and Senator Puplick as to that body. I have heard no reason so far which would persuade me that at this moment the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs should undertake a parallel investigation. For that reason I am content to wait for the Corporate Affairs Commission report to be made public.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened to the debate. I think the matter of Negri River Corporation Ltd is an eminently suitable matter on which a Senate committee could undertake a follow-up to what has already been done by a Senate committee. If a case were made out that it was practicable and timely for a committee to do so I would have thought that it would be appropriate for the matter to be referred to that committee. But for some time I have believed that we need to introduce a new system in relation to references to committees which would provide for a two-stage procedure whereby a question is raised as to whether or not a matter should be referred to a Senate committee and the committee or some other group then considers how practical and timely it is for a committee to investigate that matter.

SPEECH.PARA: What we have before us tonight is an example of that procedure. Because Senator Evans gave notice of his motion last week and because the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs was able to meet yesterday the Senate now has before it, in effect, a report in which a majority of members of the committee which it was proposed should take the reference stated that for various reasons which have been explained by them they do not regard it as appropriate at this stage. So although prima facie I would have supported the motion I do not think we can do so in the face of a report from the Standing Committee saying that at the moment it does not think it should have the reference. From the point of view of the Senate's procedures I believe that a Senate committee's preliminary report as to whether it is practical, timely and appropriate for it to have a reference is something that should be taken not as final but certainly as being of considerable persuasiveness to this chamber when dealing with a proposition such as that contained in Senator Evans's motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you support a reference to a select committee?

—Let us consider that matter if and when it comes up. I just indicate that I do not think it would be unusual or impossible for the Senate to look at this matter but I think we have to pay regard to the report which has been put before us, which is certainly most persuasive, and which states that the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee does not consider it appropriate at this stage. For that reason I do not propose to support Senator Evans's motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.TITLE: ADVISORY COUNCIL FOR INTER-GOVERNMENT RELATIONS AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 February, on motion by Senator Messner:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose to speak a little more briefly than the subject matter of this Bill perhaps deserves, not least because of the time that I have already taken today trespassing on the patience of the Senate. Nonetheless some important issues are raised by it and I think it needs at least some serious consideration by this chamber. The Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations was established by statute in 1976 on a co-operative national basis and has been operative since 1977. It consists of 21 members-representatives of the Commonwealth, States and local government, some citizens and observers from the two Territories. Its function is essentially to advise, as might be expected, on matters of intergovernment relations generally, subject from time to time to direction from the Premiers Conference as to the manner of its investigations and also to act on the basis of more explicit references to it by the Premiers Conference from time to time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill simply puts the structure and organisation of the ACIR on a proper statutory basis. To that extent its terms are quite uncontroversial. The only extraordinary feature of the legislation is the time that it has taken for it to be brought on. Problems in the formalised structure of the institution have been allowed to linger on for several years. That has caused a number of significant practical difficulties, some of which have been referred to in recent times in this chamber. I refer in particular to the problem of getting the accounts of the organisation properly audited by, as was always intended, the Tasmanian Auditor-General, Tasmania being the State in which the Council is physically located. The Tasmanian Auditor-General took the view that not only did he have no responsibility but also he had no power to audit the books of the Council in the absence of any express statutory authority to that effect. That kind of nonsense is now being resolved by the passage, at last, of this Bill. Its terms are welcomed by the Opposition.

I do not purport to be a fervent admirer of the activities of the ACIR. Its actions for the most part tend to be a little too cautious, its approach a little too tunnel-visioned, for my taste but at the same time I believe sufficiently in the utility or the potential utility of the organisation to have been participating in its deliberations for the last year or so, first as a stand-in deputy for Mr Lionel Bowen, one of the Opposition nominees, and more recently as a member of the Council in my own right. I believe from that perspective that the work of the organisation, whilst in many ways frustrating because of its inevitable tendency to be preoccupied with compromises and hastening slowly, nonetheless has a real potential utility in making this cumbrous federal system of ours ultimately work.

The Council is staffed by a highly competent group of researchers led by its current director, Mr Mark Lynch. It has produced a large number of working papers and information papers and has now commenced to produce a flow of significant reports containing useful recommendations on a variety of subject matters. Initially the scope of the activities of the organisation was deliberately small-scale and narrow. The first task undertaken by the Council was the production of a report on the question of interchange of personnel between different levels of government to develop an understanding of the way in which the system operated in other jurisdiction and to help, as a result, make the wheels turn a little more easily in the future. Nothing much seems to have happened by way of implementation of that report, even though there has been no significant dissent from any quarter in Australia as to the merit of the recommendations in it. The major ongoing research project of the Council is simply entitled 'Relationships' reference. Indeed, the terms of reference given to the Council by the Premiers Conference are about as wide as possible, namely:
An examination of the relationships which should exist between Federal, State and local governments.

It is the development of a detailed approach to that reference that has preoccupied the Council for the last two years or more with the primary focus of activity being on the role of local government in the total system. A lot of empirical research as well as more conceptual work is being done to try to identify the strengths and, more obviously, the weaknesses of local government and to identify ways in which the system might be able to work more equitably and efficiently. The more specific matters that can be identified as also being the subject matter of the Council's concern are particular projects, such as intergovernmental relations in subject areas such as care of the aged, and another study on the Australian Loan Council which has more recently been embarked upon, not with the total support of State and Federal treasuries but nonetheless with sufficient arm's length willingness to participate to make it possible that some fresh approach will be identified and articulated in terms of the operation of our public borrowing system.

Perhaps the most immediately useful report that the ACIR has so far produced is a very recent one on the subject of roads or what ought to be the responsibility of the respective level of governments for road funding and for road administration in this country-a reference prompted by the consideration that the road funding arrangements that had prevailed for a number of years were winding to a close in June last year. That period was subsequently extended by another year. It was based also on a fairly universal recognition that there were some fundamental problems in the multiplicity of authorities and agencies with responsibility in this area, and some fundamental irrationalities in the way in which funds were disbursed.

I think it has been generally acknowledged that the quite substantial report, prepared largely at the instance of one of the research directors of the Council, Mr John Jamison, has in fact been a quite substantial and thought-provoking contribution to the debate and one which may indeed have considerable influence. I think it ought to be mentioned also that the annual reports of the organisation that will appear in the future are likely to amount to quite a useful commentary on federal affairs or intergovernmental issues as they are breaking in a whole variety of contexts and environments. The kind of record that will be built into the terms of that annual report in future will, I think, be quite a useful resource document.

The question that concerns me more than all this, however, is not so much the past and the present activities of the Council but where it might go in the future. It is one view-it is probably the prevailing view, and indeed an understandable view-that the survival and the continued funding by the various governments to the Council depends essentially on its doing no more than producing small and incremental recommendations about various things in a context in which society never moves fast enough or far enough to offend more than a small minority of politicians and bureaucrats at any given time. But in that way lies a recipe for survival for this and most other sorts of organisations within the governmental system. But I suspect that the real credibility of this organisation, measured from some retrospective platform of years hence, and the real utility of the organisation for the future of the nation will increasingly depend on its willingness to tackle some rather harder issues, some rather bigger issues, some issues which are likely to stir the possums and really to create opposition, perhaps in the first place wrong-headed or pigheaded opposition, and to do the sorts of things which will require people to rethink the basic assumptions on which they operate in participating in intergovernmental relations.

One of the issues which I think it would be desirable to see the ACIR confronting, at least as a longer term project, is the future of tax sharing arrangements in this country. It must be apprarent to everyone by now that Fraser's fiscal federalism-I am tempted to continue the alliteration down a rather different track-is, at the very least, a fraud. This is a question which is, of course, assuming a great deal of prominence and a great deal of significance with the winding up in this financial year of the Whitlam tax sharing formula which has indeed been about the only thing so far which has kept the States financially viable against the Huns and the Visigoths of the Commonwealth Treasury, bent as they are on winding back public sector expenditure, and that channelled through the States in particular.

It should be obvious that the kind of new federalist fiscal model that has been developed and articulated on so many platforms around the country by Mr Fraser since 1975 is no more and never has been anything more than an excuse for winding back Commonwealth participation and, more importantly, Commonwealth financial grants to a whole variety of activities-roads, housing, urban development and community-based health and welfare services, those areas simply being, I suppose, the most obvious and conspicuous examples of where the winding down of Commonwealth funding is hurting most and is operating most visibly. It ought to be perfectly obvious that this has gone on because the present Government, politically sophisticated as it undoubtedly is, knows all too well that the ideological appeal to federalist instincts that in fact it has been making in developing the new federalist model-the calling on the States to carry out their own responsibilities and to assume the financial responsibilities for the functions they in fact exercise--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I think Senator Evans's eloquence deserves more attention. Senator Kilgariff, please have your conversation outside; do not have your back to the Chair. Proceed, Senator Evans.
—Bless you, Mr Acting Deputy President. Your intervention is much appreciated. The eloquence has been turned off at the tap by virtue of that intervention.
—It is not fair to a speaker to have to talk with that sort of distraction.

—That goes for my colleague on my right from South Australia, too, not to mention my colleague from the Australian Capital Territory. Mr Fraser knows perfectly well that the motions he is going through, the ideological appeal he is making to the States to carry the can for the functions that they exercise and to assume the fiscal responsibility for financing those functions, is no more and no less than a bluff-a big 'B' bluff. It has ever been thus. The trouble is that the world has moved on since the 1942 uniform tax case and all the atmospherics and the emotion that went with it. Despite the continuance of the rhetoric of States' rights, the reality is that, as every State Premier in this country knows, for the States to impose their own income tax surcharges to pick up the financial burdens where the Commonwealth grants leave off is no more and no less than signing ones own electoral death warrant. That has been the attitude not only of Labor Premiers but also of conservative premiers, even those who waxed most indignantly rhetorical about the inequities of cutting off Federal funds and those who have waxed most enthusiastically rhetorical about the new federalist model and the recession of power back from the Commonwealth to the States where it rightfully belongs.

SPEECH.PARA: I am reminded on these occasions, as I have been reminded on numerous occasions over the years, of that famous ditty penned by Sir Robert Garran at a Premiers Conference, or it may have been a Loan Council meeting, in the early 1950s when, as Sir Robert Menzies used to do very successfully, indeed, once again he succeeded in calling the States' bluff on a question of restoration to the States of their own income taxing powers. It became perfectly apparent that the States, whilst they were prepared to carry on about the matter publicly, had no such intention. The ditty by Sir Robert Garran, with which many honourable senators will no doubt be familar and which was pushed down the table at the Premiers Conference, was to the following effect:
We thank you for the offer of a cow
But we can't milk
And so we answer now
We answer in a loud resounding chorus
Please keep the cow and do the milking for us.

That is exactly the attitude which has prevailed ever since the uniform tax arrangements became a fait accompli in the wartime circumstances of the 1940s, and despite all the huffing and puffing and all the nonsense about new Federal fiscal models, that is the contemporary reality. If we are to get some equity back into the distribution of the revenue derived by the public purse in the payout between the Commonwealth Government and the States we must somehow elevate our conceptual thinking beyond the banal and rhetorical level which operates at the moment. Whether the ACIR will ever have the clout, the competence or the vision to impose some more rational tax-sharing formulae and conceptual apparatus to justify it than that which prevails at the moment, I do not know; but I would like to see the attempt made.

The second area in which I would like to see the ACIR playing a more prominent role in the future in rationalising governmental relations is the whole question of reshaping the constitutional demarcation of powers between the Commonwealth and the States. There are an innumerable number of familiar areas in which the present constitutional division of powers limits the Commonwealth's competence to quite a restricted range of matters, being those within the rather narrow vision of the founding fathers in the 1890s developed by them against an ideological perception in favour of small government generally and small central government in particular. There has been a general recognition, I believe, among many sections of the community-unfortunately that does not extend as far as the State Premiers and many State politicians-that there does need to be some reordering of the present layout of responsibilities. One of the most obvious areas in which the cry of pain has been heard, and heard often, is that of family law-and indeed a whole variety of other kinds of laws affecting personal status of one kind or another-where there remains a quite unfortunate division of responsibilities, and limitations really, as to what the Commonwealth can do compared with the States.

There is a whole variety of safety issues-road safety and occupational safety-in respect of which again there is an incapacity, as present consititutional arrangements stand, for any kind of uniform law to be applied except at the cost of years and years of negotiation, very often resulting in the lowest common denominator compromises of the kind with which we are all too familiar in the corporations and securities area now. In this morning's Press an organisation raised a question about the absence of a capacity to pass national laws with respect to facilities for the disabled. That is another obvious area where the multiplicity of jurisdictional responsibilities militate against rational decision-making and rational provision for the interests of the community. Defamation law and other perhaps more controversial areas of the law affecting the media could also arguably benefit from more national vision than is possible under the present Constitution.

I simply mention also a much more financially significant point than any of those; that is, the whole question of constitutional power to deal with the resources boom and its economic implications. We are all too familiar with the kind of competitive bidding to attract multinational investments that has been so characteristic of the Australian resource scene and energy development scene in recent years and how States have been falling over each other to underbid and to sell off energy resources at the lowest possible price at the expense of the overall interests of the nation. I think that is easy to argue and to establish. We are forced into that position by the absence of constitutional power to impose rational national planning on these very vexed issues. There are many more points that could be made along those lines, but I think they are all familiar and speak for themselves. If anyone is to bring a fresh vision to bear and perhaps be the vehicle through which some of the necessary thinking can be done, maybe it is the ACIR in the longer term.

The largest question of all and, I suppose, the one that the ACIR, along with everyone else, is most reluctant to tackle, is the question of the whole future of the federal structure itself with the three-tier system so far, it seems, being taken for granted by everyone. It involves one Comonwealth with, as we have seen, limited constitutional powers; six States with rather larger powers but acting within quite irrationally and arbitrarily drawn nineteenth century colonial boundaries; and two Territories, one of which is aspiring to statehood although it has a total population not much bigger than a grand final football crowd. Of course, I refer to one in Melbourne, not in Sydney.

TALK.START.PARA: —We haven't got a big enough stadium.

—Sydney might have one big enough in Parramatta but I do not want to get into that argument. In addition, we have over 900 units of local government of one kind or another. So to govern a population of not much more than 14 million people we have nearly 1,000 separate legislative chambers, approximately 1,000 full time parliamentarians and, on top of that, another 10,000 or more part time parliamentarians in the shape of councillors for local government. Australia is one of the most spectacularly governed countries in the world in terms of quantity, if not quality. When one looks at the bare statistics I have outlined, this question arises: Is this the most rational way of governing this country or indeed any other? I have always been impressed when I have considered these things by what that well known Liberal Sir Percy Spender had to say on these matters in his 1972 opus called Politics and a Man. This is something that ought to be engraved on the hearts of some honourable senators opposite who are all too inclined to accept alternative propositions and to give them shibboleth status. On page 51 Sir Percy stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Nothing has, however, retarded the concept of Australian unity so much as the public attitude and performance of the State-righters and the posturing of State politicians.

There it is. That comes from the heart. That comes from one of the great, gilt-edged Tory politicians of all time. I will be prepared to concede that he did not know much about international law, but he knew a fair bit about the pigheadedness, the stubbornness and the tunnel vision of the States-righters, the politicians who, I regret, operate most of the powers that are available to governments in this country.

For years I have also been impressed, as have most honourable senators on this side of the chamber and even a handful on the other side-although it is more than their preselections are worth ever to admit it-by the whole approach to rethinking the federal structure that has been most effectively articulated over the decades by Gough Whitlam, former Labor Prime Minister, and by others who, like him, have seen a more rational governmental future for Australia in very different terms from the continuation into the hereafter of this leaden, three-tier system that we have at the moment. I am referring, of course, to the regional model of Australia's future which would be built up around the concept of a central government exercising the major legislative and executive powers, in particular the major powers that are necessary to be exercised in the national interest so far as resource allocation is concerned, but with a very substantial devolution of actual on-the-ground administrative decision-making in addition to a significant devolution of locally relevant legislative powers to perhaps 70 or 80 regional assemblies around Australia which would be somewhat intermediate in size and also in terms of powers between the present local governments and the existing State governments. That is the kind of model which assumed notoriety-I suppose that is the only word for it-during the Whitlam years. 'Whitlam centralism' became the kind of catch cry against which a generation of political reputations were made and broken.

I think it would be unfortunate if this kind of thinking, which is much more participatory, much more genuinely democratic and much more devolved in its intended operation than its critics have ever given it credit for, did not remain part of our vocabulary and our thinking when it comes to intergovernmental relations. It ought certainly to remain part of the conceptual apparatus that a body such as the ACIR and its staff continues to bring to bear in thinking about a more rational division of powers in this country. I acknowledge the extent to which vested interests and the strength of parochial preoccupations are absolutely fundamental phenomena in the Australian political scene at the moment and how irrelevantly visionary a lot of this must seem. Nonetheless, I hope that there will be a willingness over the decades to come to explore just some of the possible alternative bases on which our whole system of government might be structured and premised, and that the ACIR might be the kind of organisation which would be prepared to take some leadership in that respect in the future. Of course, it is always easier to tackle easy questions than hard ones. It is always easier for bodies of this kind, for Senate committees even, to make easy decisions rather than to approach and to contemplate the making of hard decisions. But if the ACIR is to become something more than a mere vehicle for the apologetic defence of the status quo, it has to think in these terms otherwise it will be an utterly worthless institution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Davidson Sen G.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bill which the Senate is looking at tonight is an amending Bill and relates to the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations. It is, as the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) and other honourable senators have said, a machinery measure and therefore is not a major piece of legislation. Nevertheless, I will take the opportunity of saying that it has very strong elements of importance because it provides the opportunity for the Senate and for any legislative body to have some general discussion upon the whole matter of government, upon the whole area of the tiers of government that we have in this country and, as Senator Evans has just said, the relationship and usefulness of those various levels of government, bearing in mind our historical structure, our geographical development and the number of people we have in this country. We can try to determine whether we can afford or benefit from not only those three tiers of government but also the fairly substantial number of people who are involved and who make their contribution. So, it gives the opportunity to the Senate and to the Parliament to look at not only the matters of this Advisory Council but also the interdependence between the various tiers of government in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations was established in 1976 and has been entrusted with the important task of improving inter-governmental co-operation. The Council is made up of representatives of the three levels of government in Australia-the Commonwealth Government, the various State governments and, of course, the all important area of local government. It carries out its task by inquiring into and reporting upon matters relating to the improvement of inter-governmental co-operation. But while this Council is constructed the way it is and while it has the responsibilities it has, it is important to observe-I am not sure that I agree with the principle-that the only matters it can inquire into and report upon are matters which are referred to it not by any one of the tiers of government but by no less a body than the Premiers Conference. However, the Bill before us, as the Minister has said, is 'aimed principally at reinforcing the Council's independence in the performance of its functions by providing for the Council to become a body corporate with its own bank account, to have control over its staffing arrangements, exempting the Council from Commonwealth and State taxation laws and by making it clear that the Council is not subject to direction by or on behalf of the Commonwealth'. In other words, this machinery Bill is designed to strengthen the Council's independence, effectiveness and usefulness in its advisory role to governments.

I have been looking at the latest annual report of the Council and two matters appear to have been referred to it for inquiry and report. Its first reference dealt with a study of the costs and benefits of an interchange of personnel between the three spheres of government. Its second reference was to examine the relationships which should exist between Federal, State and local government. This has been described as the relationship reference while the earlier one was described as the interchange reference. Neither of these inquiries impressed me as being of particular significance yet I think it is very important that this Council, carrying as it does a membership drawn from the whole range of the tiers of government, spend its time in conducting this sort of examination because it will confirm the kinds of results that have been reached by all manner of people who, over the years, have looked at the relationships between governments and the possibilities of interchange. In 1978, a Premiers Conference suggested that the Council, when examining the reference about the relationships between Federal, State and local governments, should concern itself with the relationships that should exist between what I will call the third tier, that is, the tier of local government, and its relationships with the Commonwealth. The inquiry into the interchange reference which relates to staffing matters has been completed and the report has been released. The Council suggested that a greater amount of co-operation might be established and understanding might be improved if there were opportunities for personnel to transfer from one to the other, thereby increasing and improving the services each to the other.

In regard to the relationship reference, it was decided to commission a number of papers. This has been carried out and honourable senators will see reference to these papers in the report. They look at specific areas of governmental relations both in this country and abroad. We have had papers presented on local government in Australia, the functions of government in Australia and the relationships between State and Commonwealth governments. Others refer to roads, housing and care for the aged. Beyond Australia, there has been a study of inter-governmental relations in England, in the United States and in the Federal Republic of Germany. While all of these papers were commissioned primarily to help the Council, they were, of course, of great interest to anyone who was interested in federations and, in particular, in inter-governmental relationships within Australia.

When we refer to the specific inquiry that dealt with the relationship between local government on the one hand and Commonwealth and State governments on the other, it is important to remember that the Council focused its attention in a number of areas. Some of these dealt with the role which local government should perform in serving ratepayers and citizens, the responsibilities of providing a community infrastructure, the matter of revenue raising capacity, the machinery for co-ordination, consultation and co-operation and, most of all, the resources required to improve the effectiveness of local government. This apparently aroused a great deal of interest because about 230 submissions were received and a whole range of public meetings and seminars were held in well over 20 centres in all of the States and in the mainland Territories. These inquiries give some indication not only of the good work which the Advisory Council is doing, but also of the kind of work it is capable of performing. I am interested in this matter because if the Council undertakes this sort of work I believe that in future it has every possibility of carrying out even wider and more significant inquiries as to how inter-government co-operation can be achieved and how inter-government understanding can be improved within Australia.

The Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations has an enormous scope. I think it is important that it is established in our community. I think it is very important that it is strengthened within our community because in a federation such as ours there are periods when and various areas in which governments-Commonwealth, State or local-come into tension or conflict one with the other over issues and some of the problems are not easily or readily resolved. The Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations can provide a lead to government in solving some of these problems. The nature of its relationship to local government is of particular interest to me. I think the strengthening of the Council for which the Bill provides will be of benefit to local government. In the local government relationships reference the Council has decided to examine the topic of revenue raising capacity. That involves the matters of financial relationships and assistance and the continuity of fiscal arrangements in our whole range of government structure.

May I recall for the Senate the discussions which we have had earlier in relation to this matter as far as local government is concerned. Honourable senators will be aware of the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act under which the Government apportions to this sphere of government a fixed amount of the country's income tax receipts. This move has been of great assistance to local government because it has allowed councils to have a considerable degree of independence and flexibility in determining their own programs, setting their own priorities and in the provision of local government services. As honourable senators will be aware, at present local government receives two per cent of the Commonwealth's personal income tax collection, a percentage which this current financial year will provide over $300m for local government in Australia. It is important to point out that this amount represents a 35 per cent increase over the funds which were made available in 1979-80. This has been of considerable benefit to local government. I believe careful attention has to be paid to the proportion of income tax revenue allocated to local government because the matter of local government financing in the 1980s is of considerable importance and significance.

We are living and working in a time when taxation reform is being widely discussed and debated both within government and public circles. There could be a move away from a personal income tax sharing system because this system has been described as a declining tax instrument. I have made this point before in dealing with legislative measures that have been put before the Senate in relation to local government and its share of total income tax revenue. There is a demand in the community for a reduction in the level of income tax. Such a reduction might well reduce the money that could flow to this level of government, that is, the area of local government. I think this has to be recognised and has to be watched because if the Council for Inter-government Relations is to have any function at all it has to exercise a very strong watching brief in this matter. It seems to me that in the years ahead local government might well be required to have a closer involvement in the decision making as far as this financial base is concerned and the financial arrangements which might be worked out. Local government will be required to have a closer and more intimate consultation with Commonwealth and State governments. I suggest that it is here that this Council which is the subject of the legislation now before the Senate can be most useful, most effective and most operative. The new powers, limited though they may seem to be, which are given to the ACIR may prove to be most useful and most effective.

As I have already mentioned, the references are directed to the Council by the Premiers Conference and the Council reports its findings to the Commonwealth and State governments as well, be it noted-may I add with some emphasis-as to the Australian Council of Local Government Associations. This body which is located here in Canberra represents local government bodies throughout Australia, but does not have the ability to initiate inquiries as do the State and Commonwealth governments subject to the approval of a Premiers Conference. It would appear to me that as the provisions of the legislation now stand the Commonwealth and the State governments in this matter of government have an advantage over the third sphere of government in Australia-local government, an area of government in Australia to which we pay a good deal of tribute and lip service but which we all readily recognise is one of the most important areas of government in Australia because it involves not only the people who are close to the action scene but also people who live and work in areas to which local government is related. Obviously there would be problems in dealing with the situation and amendments might very well be proposed in due course to allow local government bodies to make suggestions directly to this Council rather than through individual members of the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations.

These things are fairly simplistic in their stating and one recognises that there are more complexities than would appear just by stating the facts. But as government systems develop in this country I think it is important, if we have any regard for federalism at all and if we have any regard for the three tiers of government, to recognise that local government has come a long way in the last 100 years and that within it there are people of authority, understanding and effectiveness and they need to be provided with the opportunity to make significant input rather than just standing back to receive whatever is agreed to be apportioned to them.

Local government and the Council of Local Government Associations feel that this Council about which we are speaking, the ACIR, is performing a good function. Local government generally believes the reports produced by the Council are of great value and are of great benefit and that they engender debate on topics which is extremely useful and upon which answers are not always readily available. I mention this because at the last three annual conferences of the Australian Council of Local Government Associations there have been resolutions of very strong support for ACIR. They have approved the work which the ACIR is doing and have undergirded the initiatives which it has taken. So the strengthening of the ACIR will be of value to the Australian Council of Local Government Associations and marks yet another step of progress in relation to relationships between the various levels of government in this country.

I want to refer to a situation in another area which, nevertheless, has a close connection to the subject matter. It exists probably more particularly in South Australia than anywhere else. This matter has been raised in this Senate many times and again as late as this afternoon. I refer to the salinity problems in the River Murray. I do not intend to initiate a debate on this area of public interest. This river flows through the States of Victoria and New South Wales and into South Australia. For many decades a salinity problem has been identified but concerted action to overcome the problem has been hampered by a lack of co-operation and co-ordination not only between the States but also between the various levels of government. I trust that honourable senators will forgive me for referring to a report with which you, Mr Acting Deputy President, are familiar. I refer to the report of the Senate Select Committee on Water Pollution. I know it is 10 years since we put that report down in the Senate, but I take this opportunity to cite a couple of paragraphs from that report. The report states:

Some Australian rivers are naturally saline. The salinity of others is increased by the actions of man. Both natural circumstances and the activities of man affect the River Murray, which has the most important salinity problem in Australia.
The report also states:

. . . there is . . . evidence indicating . . . a lack of co-ordination between the States, an even more lamentable lack of anti-pollution powers among the organisations involved with the management and use of the Murray, and a pressing need for some overall organisation which could analyse the problem and effectively solve it.

I know that these sentences were written well over 10 years ago and many things have happened since then. I emphasise the quotation which emphasised that there was a lack of co-ordination between the levels of government and between the States. I would commend to the ACIR for the work which it is already doing in the area of governmental relations. It should assist or even pave the way for co-operation between the various levels of government within this country. It should find a solution or at least call the authorities together to find a solution to this one problem on which I place some emphasis. Of course, there are other areas where problems have arisen. Their solution has been delayed because of intergovernmental relations difficulties and by a failure of governments at various levels to exercise clear constitutional powers.

The Bill has my support. The Council has my support; but I draw attention, with some emphasis, to the statement of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) when introducing the Bill. Referring to the amendments, he said:
These amendments are aimed principally at reinforcing the Council's independence in the performance of its functions . . .

I hope that that will be borne out, as the Minister hopes. One of the problems we have with the establishment of organisations of this kind seems to me to be the degree of inactivity that seems to come from them. The intergovernment situation in Australia seems to me to be at a watershed position. The way that this Advisory Council performs its duties will influence the way governments and authority in this country develop. Local government stands to gain a great deal if it is given room to move and, what is more, the wherewithal to operate. We seem to be in danger of drowning in a sea of intergovernmental organisations and councils. Inquiries multiply, references proliferate and no one can make a decision. Everyone is waiting for some report. Everyone is waiting for someone else to do something. State Ministers seem to refer back and public servants seem to be unable to pronounce or even to decide.

This Advisory Council is to be supported. It is to be undergidered and it is to be strengthened. It is to be supplied with leadership, with encouragement and with the opportunity to move, to make decisions and to do things for the good of this federal system which we have. I hope that this Bill will find a reflection in the new activity and the new assertion which this Council will have and that before too long we will be able to see the benefits that will flow from this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly I would like to direct some comments to the remarks made by the two previous speakers. My colleague, Senator Evans, was something akin to an insider speaking out. He is an insider because he is a member of the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations. I will be quite different. I will be an outsider looking in. Because I am an outsider looking in I might have a quite different approach from that of my colleague, Senator Evans. He looked to the future and to what might happen to the ACIR. I will be looking at the Council as it exists at present. I certainly will not be as conceptually orientated as my colleague was but I will look rather more at the practical aspects of the Council.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to make some remarks about some of the comments made by Senator Davidson. He mentioned that at the moment local authorities are guaranteed 2 per cent of income tax collections from the Commonwealth. Local authorities will have to be wary in future-and as I have moved around and spoken to members of local authorities I have seen that they realise that they will have to be wary in future-if there is a major shift in the focus of taxation by the Commonwealth Government. If there is a shift and if income tax collections as a proportion of the total tax collected by the Commonwealth become smaller, it may be that the local authorities will have to have a higher proportion of the income tax collections or share in some of the other taxation that is being used to make up for the income tax collections. I was quite taken with what I thought was a significant and worthwhile suggestion by Senator Davidson. He suggested that local government authorities should have an input into the ACIR. This sort of input would be necessary if we found that local authorities become financially disadvantaged because of a shift in the way that revenue is being raised by the Federal Government.

The existence of the Advisory Council recognises the fact that Australia has a three-tier interdependent system of government. The authority of the Federal Government is clearly set out in our Constitution and by implication, so too is the authority of each of the State governments. Those powers for which the Federal Government does not have competence-the residual powers, as they are often called-lie with the State governments. On the other hand, local authorities owe their existence to State government legislation and thus their powers vary throughout the Commonwealth. For the effective functioning of government in Australia it is imperative that these three levels of government co-operate with one another. The Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations was established to improve such intergovernment co-operation.

The Council has 22 members. Five members come from the Commonwealth Parliament. One member comes from each of the six State parliaments. There are six local government representatives, and five citizens appointed by the Prime Minister after consultation with the State Premiers. For some time Queensland was not represented on the Advisory Council. This fact was something of a disappointment to me because I, as a senator for Queensland, had hoped that Queensland would participate from the very beginning. In mid-June 1979 Queensland became represented and has been a participant on the Council ever since.

In general the Council operates under the direction of the Premiers Conference. The amendment Bill now being debated is designed to strengthen the independence of the Council. At first glance criticism of the Council would appear to be indefensible. After all, who would suggest that there should not be co-operation between our three levels of government? I certainly do not suggest that. I suggest that now that the Bill is being debated it is timely that some of the activities of the Council were examined critically. I would like to mention the financial commitment that centres upon the Council. Considerable funds are required for the upkeep of the ACIR and these funds come from the Commonwealth Government, the State governments and the Australian Council of Local Government Associations.

I would like to outline some of the receipts of the Council for the latest year for which I have any information, the year ended 31 August 1979. The Commonwealth contributed $156,500; the New South Wales Government contributed $35,500; the Victorian Government contributed $30,000; the South Australian Government contributed $17,500; the Western Australian Government contributed $17,000; the Tasmanian Government contributed $13,500, which would be a considerable sum to Tasmania; and the Australian Council of Local Government Associations contributed $30,000. All of these sums are significant sums to the bodies involved.

It is worthwhile having a look at how this money was spent. Salaries and payments in the nature of salary amounted to $189,453. This represents a fair slice of the money that was contributed by the Commonwealth, the States and local government associations. I was also somewhat amazed to see that fares amounted to $37,000 and that permanent premises were purchased for $106,000. A total of $431,000 was spent.

I mention these figures because it is worthwhile having a look at what contribution the ACIR is making if this sort of money is involved. In terms of total budget, expenditure of the magnitude that I outlined is not large but, on the other hand, it is an amount which should not escape scrutiny. For half a million dollars a year one would hope that some significant steps towards intergovernmental co-operation were being made. With that in mind it is pertinent to examine what the Premiers Conference has referred to the Council for inquiry and report. The third report-the latest report available-outlines that in April 1976 the interchange program was referred to the Council. This concerned a study of how personnel could be interchanged between spheres of government. The Council was asked to make a recommendation on how this could be implemented.

The relationships reference has been mentioned by other speakers. On 24 January 1978 the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) suggested that with regard to the relationships reference the Council should study, at the start, the relationship which should exist between local government and the Commonwealth and State governments. These two references-the interchange reference and the relationships reference-are the only references that have gone to the Council so far. The interchange reference has been completed and a report has been presented to this Parliament. The report on the interchange reference is mentioned in the latest report of the Council as 'Staff Interchanges between Governments in Australia'. This report outlined procedures for short term interchange of staff. The recommendations in the report tend to formalise existing practices. No co-ordinating committee has yet been set up for the interchange of staff.

Early in 1980 an interdepartmental committee was set up to consider how the report could best be implemented. The major problem seems to be the portability of superannuation. My information is that this has been referred to the State Public Service boards and superannuation authorities for further consideration. The fact that this report has been referred to an IDC implies some level of government acceptance of the report's recommendations. I have been informed that since this report has been referred to the IDC, the Commonwealth Public Service Board has displayed a greater inclination to arrange short term interchanges. If this is so it supports the conclusion that there is a certain level of government support. But it is well to question whether this report of the Council has yet had a major impact.

It is fine to have a report; it is fine to refer that report to an IDC. But something more than that is required before the Council's report will be seen to have had a major impact. I am not implying that nothing will be achieved as a result of this reference, but so far little seems to have been achieved. If this is the case it is a pity that we have all the work done to provide a report which will achieve so very little. For half a million dollars a year some positive results are warranted, not merely reports, IDC discussions and referring a problem back to the States.

There has been one published report concerning the relationship reference. An examination of this report indicates that much work has been carried out in respect of that reference. Nevertheless, to the outsider, there does not appear to be any prospect of an early implementation of the findings from this study. In the second annual report a number of studies which have been undertaken by academics are mentioned. As a one-time academic I have no objection to work being carried out by well-qualified people from universities and colleges of advanced education. Yet I do have doubts whether any tangible benefits are likely to come from the research which is being undertaken. It may be open to question that this type of research should be funded through this Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations. Perhaps it should be funded through the universities themselves.

Together with other senators, I support the concept of the ACIR and the amending legislation which is being debated. But let us not allow ourselves to be so supportive that we do not critically examine the Council's work and achievements. It has a real role to play in intergovernment relations in Australia and has the potential to achieve much for the three levels of government. Even though the Council must operate in accordance with directions from the Premiers Conference, it is incumbent on members of the Federal Parliament to scrutinise its work and to see that the Commonwealth, the States and local authorities are obtaining value for money. In this regard, namely, the scrutiny of the activities of the Council, I level another criticism. I hope that the criticism will be taken as a constructive one. Section 6 of the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations Act directs that as soon as practicable after 31 August each year the Council shall prepare an annual report. That report is then to be furnished to the Prime Minister, the Premiers and the Australian Council of Local Government Associations. Section 7 of the Act requires that the Prime Minister table a copy of the report within 15 sitting days after he has received a copy of it.

Against that type of information it is worthwhile noting that the first report for the year ended 31 August 1977 was presented to Parliament on 1 November 1977. I regard that short time between the end of the year and the tabling of the report as quite acceptable. A prompt tabling of the Council's report allows senators and members to have up to date information on the Council's activities. In the next year the situation was not as good. The second annual report for the year ended 31 August 1978 did not come into the Parliament until 20 March 1979. This means that the report's information was at least six months old before senators and members could read it. However, the latest report-the third report-for the year ended 31 August 1979 was not tabled until 26 August 1980. At that stage the information was five days short of being 12 months out of date. Those senators and members who want to fulfil their duty to scrutinise the activities of the Council are being frustrated by the late tabling of these reports. This criticism does not apply to tabling of the first report. That was tabled quite promptly. The tabling of the second report was not quite as prompt as the tabling of the first. But the third report was tabled in this Parliament quite late. It was tabled nearly 12 months after the end of the period to which the report referred. There is no reason why reports should not or could not be tabled as quickly as was the first report. All those who are responsible should see that this occurs.
