In the course of my comments this evening I have made some criticisms-some mild criticisms, I think-of the ACIR. The concept of the ACIR is something that we in the Federal Parliament should all support. On the other hand, it is a body that requires finance from the Federal Parliament. Because of this we should be able to scrutinise the activities of the ACIR and scrutinise them clearly. I trust that my comments and criticisms will be taken in the light in which they are intended. They are intended to be constructive criticisms. I hope those who are responsible will take them as such.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I stand tonight briefly to make a request and perhaps a criticism in relation to the present situation, as I see it, within the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations. I have had quite a lot to do with this Council over the last four years. I retired in the last few months from the Council. I was one of the foundation Commonwealth Government members of the Council. The Council has five representatives from the Commonwealth Government. I served for the first two terms during the setting up period of the Council. I am fairly aware of the work that it has done, where it is going and what has brought it about. The Premiers conferences found over the years when they were debating various matters there was a necessity for someone to carry out research on the various matters that came before them. So the ACIR was formed so that the Premiers could refer various matters to the Council which is comprised of 22 members. These 22 members, as other honourable senators have said, are from the Federal government, State governments, local government and chosen citizens from around Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Colston made some remarks on the ACIR expenditure. Perhaps he did not realise that the amount of money that was spent in purchasing a headquarters was necessary. That body is situated in Hobart. It was felt that it should be in Hobart as a clear indication to all that whilst the ACIR was set up under a Federal Act, it really was of State interest and was not really a part of the Commonwealth Government. The ACIR has been particularly jealous to ensure that it did not get the image of being Canberra based. Many of its meetings are held around Australia. Since that body was inaugurated it has travelled widely and in carrying out its inquiries, many citizens have appeared before it throughout Australia.

It is not my intention to go through the various amendments in the legislation that have been outlined. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) who is in charge of the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations Amendment Bill 1981 has clearly indicated what the amendments are all about. Really, the Bill proposes to make the Council more autonomous. Once again, the Commonwealth Government is clearly indicating with these amendments that it is making the ACIR stand on its own two feet and that it cannot be looked upon in any way as a Commonwealth instrumentality. I believe that this is essential because, as other honourable senators have said, it is a body that has to bring about cohesion and co-operation among the three tiers of Government. From the commencement of the ACIR the various States have been represented. The two Territories-the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory-did not actually have representation but participated in an advisory, honorary capacity. Perhaps this was all right in 1976 when the Council was established, but in regard to the Northern Territory the situation is now very different because in 1978 the Northern Territory achieved responsible self-government. The Northern Territory now has all those responsibilities that a State has. I have no doubt that at some time in the future the Territory--

TALK.START.PARA: —Except for national parks.

—The Minister said: 'Except for national parks'. Perhaps that situation may be corrected at some time in the future, perhaps even before statehood is granted to the Northern Territory as I hope it will be. The Northern Territory has developed in a different way from the Australian Capital Territory. The Australian Capital Territory was given the opportunity some time ago to have more of a voice in its own affairs and it rejected that opportunity. The Northern Territory has continued to grow. Despite this, the standing of the Northern Territory in the ACIR, has not changed. It has been represented by an advisory member. I commend the Council for treating the members who came from the Territories, as much as possible, as full members. They participated in debates and so on. The fact is that under the present legislation they are looked upon merely as advisory members and not as full members. The Minister responsible for this legislation has clearly indicated the attitude of the Commonwealth Government; that is, that the Northern Territory should participate in the ACIR as a full member. Despite this, it has not come about. I am disappointed that in the legislation before us tonight an amendment to make the Northern Territory a full member, as all the States are, is not included. This is despite the fact that the Minister and the Commonwealth Government wish it. I am disappointed that some States still stand back from giving their agreement that the Northern Territory should get full representation.
—They tried to stop us having senators, didn't they?

—Yes, that happened too. Perhaps we may see more of this attitude. I think the States of Australia must realise now that the Northern Territory is growing up. Its citizens have a right to be represented on various organisations. They are not represented, as I believe they have the full right to be on the ACIR.

SPEECH.PARA: My point in standing up tonight is to be highly critical of the States which are prepared to frustrate the decision that the Northern Territory should be represented. I cannot imagine why the States-I think probably only two States-have held back in giving their consent. I can only wonder at the reason for this. Is it jealousy? What is it? Do they not realise that the Territory is growing up and it has a right to participate? I leave it at that. I demand that those States-or the State-that will not give permission for the Northern Territory to be represented on the ACIR reconsider their situation and in the near future consent to the Commonwealth Government's request that further amendments be passed to the legislation to allow the Northern Territory to be a fully participating member.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —In 1969 the foremost authority on Federal financial relations, Professor Russell Mathews of the Australian National University, described our federal system as 'the chief factor responsible for economic inefficiency and inadequacy in the public sector' and called our system 'a yoke around the necks of Australian people'. When the Australian Labor Party came to office in December 1972 some of this burden was eased by the Whitlam Government. Substantial reforms were made to the relationships that existed then between the Commonwealth and the States. The Opposition believes that the Fraser Government has now turned the clock back to the stage we were at when Professor Mathews made that statement in 1969.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us analyse the Advisory Council. We recognise, of course, that it is just an advisory council for inter-government relations. In other words, it is a body that meets from time to time with representatives from the six States, local government and the Australian government for the purpose of reviewing the relationships particularly relating to finance and advising the Commonwealth about the sort of financial arrangements that ought to be entered into. That is a noble perspective and one which the Australian Labor Party supports. In fact, what we did in government in 1972-75 was to set in train the sort of processes which this legislation embodies. The amendment seeks to make some improvement.

It seems to me that we have to analyse the purpose of the Federal government and recognise the role that it plays in the process of government in Australia. It seems to me that we ought clearly to understand that part of the central role of our national government is to create a society of equal opportunity for the provision of goods and services for our citizens, to help the disadvantaged in the community and to enact such laws and provide funds that will enable all our citizens to partake of the services provided by government. Because of the way in which our Federal system has evolved-or should I say staggered from 1901 to where it is today-we recognise that there are other arms of government that have particular and specific areas of responsibility. Part of the obligations of the Federal Government is to assist those other public bodies to carry out their duties. Of course, as honourable senators are aware, the States have tremendous responsibilities in respect of hospital administration, education and the administration of a whole range of social services and public work activities. It would take much too long to enumerate the responsibilities which fall upon State governments. They would be known to honourable senators.

In addition, we have, of course, a role which has become of more importance in the post war years. This concerns the increasing role played by local government in the scheme of government and the increasing areas of responsibility passed down to it by State governments and the impact of policies made at the national level on the responsibilities of local government itself. Clearly, of course, if a national government is to carry out its responsibilities it has to provide funds to State governments and to local government so that their particular areas of responsibility can be carried out. I think that in round figures the policy of the Fraser Administration is to bring about 100,000 migrants to Australia each year. If that policy is continued over a 10-year period about an additional million people will have to be provided with services by both State and local government. Therefore, there is an obligation in pursuance of the responsibilities of government at that level to follow through the policies which are solely the responsibility of the national government.

As Senator Kilgariff correctly stated, probably we have reached the stage where we need to see the Northern Territory involved in this process. After all, the whole purpose of the Advisory Council and the process which is set in train here is to act as a conveyor belt for the difficulties and problems of the other arms of government as well as to integrate the policies enunciated by the national government. Of course, the role of the Federal government as distinct from those other arms of government is to intervene in the machinery of government at the national level, for example, the economy, when private actions are taken by corporations or other interest or power groups within our society which affect the rights of others. So often we hear of the rights of people that are affected by the actions of trade unions but we rarely consider how the rights of individuals are affected by the actions of corporations-particularly the big corporations. Surely we are starting to see some of the results flowing from the unplanned activities of these corporations as our resources boom in this country gets underway.

If the Government were seriously concerned with reforming the state of inter-government relations in Australia, the provisions now being inserted in the Bill would have been inserted a long time ago. Whilst the Opposition recognises that we are dealing only with an advisory council, we ought to set ourselves the task of getting that advisory council's house in order efficiently and quickly so that we can see meaningful dialogue and meaningful action on the subject of inter-government relations. What has been the policy of the Fraser Government since it came to office in 1975? There has been the development of a concept which it has called co-operative federalism in Australia. This is pertinent when we refer to the Advisory Council which has such a wide charter. I draw the attention of the Senate to one section of the Bill about which I feel uneasy. I refer to clause 6 of the Bill which states:
Section 4 of the Principal Act is amended by inserting after sub-section (1) the following sub-section:
(1A) in the performance of its function, the Council shall not be subject to any directions other than directions referred to in sub-section (1).
This particularly refers to the meaning of 'direction' as amplified by section 4 (2) of the Act. It is necessary for me to quote from sub-section (2) which states:

The reference in sub-section (1) to directions given at a Premiers' Conference shall be read as a reference to directions given by the Prime Minister and the Premiers of the participating States, or their representatives, at a conference known as a Premiers' Conference.

The criticism by Senator Kilgariff has some relevance to this section. We can see from this that the combination of the Commonwealth and the States has an advantage over the third level of government-local government-because it is not even represented at the Premiers Conference. So if there is any ground for the criticism that Senator Kilgariff has made, I think it is equally valid for me to make a criticism about local government not being represented at Premiers Conferences. It will be recalled that this was one of the issues considered by the Whitlam Government at the time of its dismissal by the former Governor-General, Mr Kerr. In my view because matters which could have been the responsibility of local government cannot be placed directly before the Council it could be said that local government, is clearly disadvantaged as a direct result of Federal Government policies and the competition taking place with respect to resources development in our country. I particularly refer to a statement made in this evening's paper.
Debate interrupted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a matter tonight which I indended to raise at Question Time today, but I did not get the chance due to a series of events. I direct my remarks tonight to Senator Baume, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. He will recall that on 27 November 1980 I asked him a question in relation to the Ralkon Agricultural Co. I will read from the Hansard to refresh his memory.
—I have it here.

—I will not need to repeat it. It is at page 109 of the Senate Hansard. The Minister will recall that I made a request of him to visit the Ralkon Agricultural Co. at Narrung and talk with the directors and shareholders. He stated, in his answer, that he would be going to South Australia and that he hoped to visit as many Aboriginal communities as he could. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Once the Parliament rises for the summer recess, it is my intention to get out and I hope to include South Australia in my program of visits.

I did see a Press report in South Australia that Senator Baume had in fact visited South Australia, but I am reliably informed that he did not visit the farming enterprise which is in question or make any contact with the company. Had the Minister done so the problems now confronting the company may well have been resolved, and I may not have had to raise this matter in the Senate tonight. I have not raised the problems confronting Ralkon in the public arena for some time now because I was of the firm belief that the previous Minister, Senator Chaney, was in the process of solving the problem that has existed there for a long time. However, this did not eventuate before a change of Ministers occurred. Senator Baume is now the third Minister for Aboriginal Affairs whom I have approached to take some firm action within the Department of Aboriginal Affairs to solve the problem. It now appears to me that none of the Ministers has been prepared to take this action. One can only assume that each one has been prepared to listen to the point of view of departmental officers rather than sit down and talk with the Aborigines themselves and learn at first hand of the problems which they have been confronted with.

I do not want to repeat the history of Ralkon to the Minister as he was the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare at the time the initial problem was referred to that Committee by the Senate. That Committee then referred the matter to the Commonwealth Ombudsman. Unfortunately, as I have explained on many occasions in the Senate, the Ombudsman had not made his report available either to the Government or the Committee before the Chairman of the company wrote to the Ombudsman and told him to forget about the whole thing because it had dragged on for so long. It was nearly two years before a report was made, and the company was disgusted with the treatment it was getting and had got before from the previous Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Viner. I was asked to bring the matter before the Senate to see whether a public inquiry could be carried out. A public inquiry never took place. It is very unfortunate for all concerned that that public inquiry did not take place so that everybody involved in this sorry state of affairs could have been called before the Committee and given evidence on oath. Then we would have solved this problem. The Government has been duck-shoving around for far too long now. As I told one of the departmental officers the other day, the matter has now come back into the political arena. We have to get some action.

I was concerned today when I received a telephone call from the management of Ralkon that Mr Wayne Prior, who is now the Regional Manager of the Aboriginal Development Commission in Adelaide, sent a telegram to the company on Friday. The company received it at 4.30 p.m. The crux of the telegram was that he would be coming down on Monday to inspect Bartlett's farm, which is one of the three farms which make up the Ralkon company, and he expected not to be denied access. That was the sort of telegram that Mr Prior sent. He expected not to be denied access. There is no way that a reply can be made by telegram when it is received at 4.30 p.m. on a Friday. Yesterday, when one of the directors of the company was about his business of looking after the farm, he came across a car that was parked on one of the roadways that goes through the farm. Who should be in the car but Mr Prior and two other people. I can only assume that one of those people was an agricultural consultant-not the one who had been doing the consultancy on the farm for some time and not at the behest of the company itself, but at the behest of the Department. That person was not in the area yesterday. We do not know the names of the people who were there. They never even had the courtesy to call at the homestead on the way through to where they parked to say that they had arrived.

Of course, if one of the directors had not come across them no one would have known they were there. The director, courteous as he is-he knew Mr Prior-spoke to him and invited him to come to Bartlett's farm to make an inspection. In fact he opened the gate for him to get on to the farm and they spent an hour on the farm in one paddock only. If they were making an assessment of the value of the farm they could not have done so by sitting in a car in the middle of a paddock for an hour.

The matter which concerns me and everybody else in relation to the Ralkon Agricultural Co. is that Mr Prior is reported to have made a statement last week that he would put Bartlett's farm on the market for sale. The Minister knows, as I have approached him on this matter, the Ralkon Agricultural Co. has been seeking title of this farm for a long time. His predecessors, Senator Chaney and Mr Viner, knew that the company wanted to get some form of title to that property so that it could spend the profits it is making on improving it. It cannot do so now because it does not own the property. The property belongs to the Government. The question I intended to ask of the Minister today was whether he could verify that Mr Prior has said that he intends to put Bartlett's farm on the market. If he does it will leave Ralkon only with a property known as Block K, the original block, and one of the blocks which is owned by the South Australian Aboriginal Lands Trust and the Point McLeay settlement itself.

Those two blocks will not be large enough to carry the stocks presently on the property. I have not checked on the number of stock. The last time I was there the company owned over 3,000 sheep and some 2,000 cattle which were all in prime condition. If the Minister cares to check the stock markets at Murray Bridge, Tailem Bend or any of those markets around there, he will see that every time the Aboriginal enterprise, Ralkon, puts cattle into the market the cattle top the market. That shows how good those farmers are. Yet three Minister were not prepared to sit down and talk to them and give them some equity in that property. The Government will not let them show to other people the pride they have and their ability to run a farm. Does the Government want to see this farm collapse so it can then say: 'Well, Aboriginals cannot run their own enterprises. We have done all we can to help them but they cannot run their own business'?

This farm which, as I have said publicly on many occasions, under the managementship of Mr Hillock, can be operated profitably. It has proved to be profitable. Yet every time those people want to do something to try to improve themselves they have run up against some of these desk wallahs in the Department who would not know a bull from a bee. Those departmental officers went out there and examined the jolly place. This is the sort of action which makes the Aboriginal people down there so damned disgusted at the way they are being treated. I plead with the Minister to get down there and talk to those people. Forget all about people such as Mr Barry Powell, who has run the Department in Adelaide for years and will not admit that the Department made a mistake many years ago; Mr Prior, who is now the Regional Manager of the Aboriginal Development Commission; and Charlie Perkins who is the Acting Chairman. Charlie would not know a bull from a bee either. As the Minister will discover if he is prepared to go down there, Charlie has made some offers to the Point McLeay Council to try to upset the whole applecart down there and bring the whole thing down so it can be said: 'We have given the Aboriginals the opportunity. They cannot run their own enterprise'.

The other matter which has raised its ugly head again-honourable senators may care to look through the minutes they have-is the continuing saga, that is, the elections to be held each year for the Point McLeay Aboriginal Council. We find that a bit of duck shoving is going on again. The Minister may have helped to get a returning officer appointed. The people of Point McLeay had no returning officer until a few weeks ago but now they have an independent returning officer to conduct the local council elections, which are due to take place on 21 March. No roles are yet available. The people cannot get them from the local council.

The chairman of directors of the Ralkon Agricultural Co., who is an Aborigine and was born on the settlement but lives just a few miles from Point McLeay in the township of Narrung, today received a letter from the chairman of the council stating that he is not entitled to vote in the council elections and is not entitled to stand as a candidate for council. Yet he was a councillor for many years. He resigned because of the mess the council was in. Today he has received a letter from Mr Wilson, the chairman of the council to say that the council will not allow him to vote and will not accept his nomination as a candidate. Honourable senators can imagine the problems that are going to rear their heads at Point McLeay if this state of affairs is allowed to continue.

I will not say any more tonight but I will continue to raise this matter not only in this chamber but also outside unless the Minister is prepared-I think he will be; I have always considered that he has a compassion for the Aboriginal cause, particularly where the Aboriginals are prepared to help themselves-to make every effort to contact the company and to go to Point McLeay, not in the company of representatives of the Aboriginal Development Commission, the people who, I feel, have let the Aborigines down. I ask the Minister not to worry about Barry Powell, if he is still a director in South Australia. He may not be; he may be in Western Australia. He was in South Australia for far too long in my view. I locked horns with him. He is the only departmental officer in any Commonwealth department with whom I have had problems in the 10 years that I have been a member of the Senate. Everybody else has been prepared to listen to reason and to do his best for the people whom he was supposed to be looking after, but not Barry Powell or some of his officers. I got on very well with some of the officers and visited the farm with them.

I again plead with the Minister to make every effort to go there before the council elections are held and to talk to the people themselves. I ask him not to be snowed by the officers of the Department. I am sure that if he looks at the record of Aboriginal affairs over the years he will find that too many Ministers have been snowed not only by departmental officers but also by people who are employed by Aboriginal communities as Aboriginal advisers and who get away with the loot on too many occasions. Senator Chaney told me that when he was Minister for Aboriginal Affairs he was not going to allow the situation to continue whereby people could be given these jobs and get away with money that is rightfully owned by Aborigines. I think the Minister knows what I am talking about without my publicising the matter. There have been court cases about it and perhaps I had best not say anything more about it. I plead with the Minister to go to Ralkon and to talk to these people. If I have been wrong in what I have been saying on behalf of these people I will be quite prepared to apologise in the Senate for what I have said over the years.

The Point McLeay Council and the Ralkon Agricultural Co. are interwoven in terms of control, ownership and interest. I have no knowledge that Bartlett's farm has been placed on the market.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say that. I said that he made the statement that he would put it on the market.

—I have no knowledge about that but I will undertake to look further at that matter. It would be of news to me. I take a moment to remind the honourable senator that on 31 December, when I responded to him, I made a number of points known in my letter which related to some of the difficulties. I advised him then that the title to Bartlett's farm is held by the Aboriginal Development Commission. The title is not held by the Department of Aboriginal affairs. It is held by an independent commission created by the Parliament. Its establishment was debated in the Senate. One of its jobs is to acquire land for Aboriginal communities, as it has done in this instance. The ADC has considered Ralkon's request that title be handed over to the company but it will not make a decision on this matter until it has considered its attitude to the holding of titles on a nationwide basis. My latest understanding is that such a decision is still to be announced by the Aboriginal Development Commission. The ADC has, however, confirmed a grant of interest in the land and it has confirmed that grant to the Point McLeay Community Council.
—They cannot run it. That is why I want you to go there.

—The honourable senator again illustrates to me his concern that that may not be the appropriate body, but that is the body to which the ADC has made the grant of interest. The ADC has agreed to consider the requests both of the Point McLeay Council and of the Ralkon Agricultural Co. once the Council can provide certain information relating to the management affairs of the Council and of Ralkon.

SPEECH.PARA: There were other matters which I referred to in my letter and to which the honourable senator adverted in his speech, which are probably better not discussed at the moment. They are matters which are before certain courts, and we do not have to discuss those things. Mr Acting Deputy President, one of the problems is that an election is coming up very soon in that community for the positions on the Point McLeay Community Council. The election is due to take place on the 28th of this month. The nominations for the Council, I think, were declared open by the returning officer two days ago-1 March-and they will close on 21 March. As happens with so many elections, there is considerable concern about the electoral role-about who is eligible to vote and who is not eligible to vote.

I understand that the Point McLeay Council has a constitution and that section 7 of that constitution lays down how the electoral role will be produced and of what it will consist. That section states that the electoral roll of eligible persons shall be prepared and maintained by the returning officer. The honourable senator said that the returning officer was appointed. He is preparing the roll. The Department has no electoral roll. It is not in possession of an electoral roll in relation to this election. Some people have asked whether the Department could supply a copy of the electoral roll. It does not have an electoral roll. It is being prepared by the returning officer.

That section of the constitution also specifies that persons may be included in that electoral roll only if they have been legally resident on the Point McLeay reserve for a period of three months prior to the date of the election. I did not produce that constitution, but it is a provision of the constitution that to be eligible to vote a person must have been legally resident there for at least three months prior-

TALK.START.PARA: —There was a Supreme Court decision a couple of elections ago at which you should look.

—I am grateful for the honourable senator's interjection. I will try to chase up that point which he has just raised. A returning officer has been appointed. I hope that the election can proceed and can be concluded. The Department is looking to see some accommodation of interest between the two groups. It seems to me to be very unfortunate whenever we have this hint of dissention or disagreement within what should be a unified Aboriginal community.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable senator raised one other matter, and that concerns an inspection which took place at Bartlett's farm. I understand he is quite correct. An officer from the ADC-I do not know who it was; Senator McLaren said it was Mr Prior-did an inspection of the ADC property yesterday. I think he is quite correct when he says that one should assume that such an inspection would have been welcomed and that an officer going out there would not have to enter as of right, that he would be welcomed. My information is that the inspection was made to gauge the condition of the property before any action might be taken to clean it up later. The Commission wanted only to get an idea of what the property is like at the moment, and only the ADC portion was inspected. I understand that some soil samples were taken and that a report will be made. If there was any lack of courtesy on the part of the ADC officer, I think that would be most unfortunate and I think it would be most regrettable. I hope that is not the course of action that officers of the Commission adopt normally.

Mr Acting Deputy President, the situation in that community is a very complicated one. I can say to the honourable senator that his suggestion that I go there as soon as possible is one which I endorse. I will look at my program. My situation is quite difficult. There are 800 Aboriginal communities in Australia, and some of them have very acute problems. I will undertake to try to visit that community at the earliest possible date.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

(4) The Australian Wool Harvesting Program was established in July 1973 by the AWC, largely in response to the recognition by industry and research bodies that a potential future problem could be emerging in relation to increasing costs of shearing and decreasing availability of adequately skilled shearers.

Since that time much development work on alternative approaches to wool harvesting which will allow cost reduction has been carried out by organisations such as CSIRO, State Departments, Universities, the AWC, private and commercial organisations and individuals. Many trials have also been conducted or observed by the AWC. All the experience gained has confirmed the substantial difficulty of producing a wool harvesting on the existing methods and a long-term viable solution to the problem of increasing costs and declining availability of skilled labour.

Whilst no effective overall solution has yet been found to the problem it has been shown from practical trials and costing studies that the total wool harvesting costs involved in conventional manual shearing of sheep held 'on the board' by shearers can be significantly reduced by the introduction and use of improved layout in shearing sheds and ancillary equipment, by the use of hydraulic self-pinning presses and the use of simplified classing procedures.

In practical trials, involving about 30,000 sheep, equipment based on the concept of mechanically restraining and positioning sheep for manual shearing by professional shearers (or less skilled hired labour) has been shown to result in per sheep costs in excess of those incurred by conventional shearing.

Several sheep restraint and positioning systems for both chain (sequence or production line) and non-chain shearing have been developed and some devices have been commercially available since 1974. Although they allow 'do-it-yourself' shearing, at least for smaller flocks, at reduced cash outlay per head compared with commercial shearing, none is outstanding on a comparative basis and few growers have shown interest in using their own or their family's labour to do their own shearing by this method.

While most early developments were related to seeking to modify and improve the existing shearing system and some promising work still continues in this area on improving the life of shearing combs and cutters, the main thrust of the wool harvesting research program is now towards novel methods of wool removal such as chemical (and/or biological) and/or automated wool harvesting methods. These novel systems are undergoing intensive scientific and engineering investigations and trials to determine technical feasibility and provide data on which future assessments of likely commercial viability can be made.

The AWC itself is not undertaking any technical research or development projects in wool harvesting. The Corporation does, however, have a responsibility under section 69 of the Wool Industry Act to remain au fait with research in progress and provide advice and recommendations to the Minister for Primary Industry in relation to projects supported by the Wool Research Trust Fund. At this stage it is not possible to identify cost savings to the degree that cost saving comparisons can be made between options. However, a major review of automated mechanical shearing is underway and will be completed by March 1981 at which time the AWC will make a decision about the future support it feels can justifiably be recommended for this technique.

The bulk of the chemical/biological defleecing work is being undertaken by CSIRO. The AWC is currently assisting the CSIRO Division of Animal Production in a preliminary economic assessment of its latest chemical shearing developments.

(7) Although the AWC has never been able to obtain a proper objective assessment of Mr Geary's actual devices, it has been able to assess the principles of restraint shearing in chain (sequence or production line) or non-chain shearing systems. Shearing trails under practical conditions involving around 30,000 sheep have demonstrated that per sheep costs of shearing in systems based on these principles using professional shearers or hired labour are unlikely to be less than those that can be achieved using conventional 'on the board' shearing in an efficient shearing shed with modern equipment and using simplified clip preparation procedures. Devices embodying the principles of Mr Geary's systems have been developed by organisations and individuals to the stage where they have been, or can be made commercially available. The poor response from woolgrowers to these devices indicates they do not see them as being sufficiently attractive over the existing shearing system.

(8) The response to this question is largely covered by that to (7). The AWC's assessment of the limitation of restraint shearing is based on practical field trials in New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia involving around 30,000 sheep. In addition, although in the past Mr Geary has been given encouragement and financial assistance from the AWC and from independent woolgrowers to produce and demonstrate his equipment, he has failed to produce equipment that could be properly assessed.

(9) As explained in the answer to (4), the use of devices that modify conventional shearing techniques has been shown not to produce significant economic savings. The Able Star handpiece has been commercially available for approximately ten years and the AWC has used it in shearing trials and public demonstrations and has described it in published brochures. Whilst it has some advantages over conventional 'down tube' shearing equipment in terms of manoeuvreability, comb and cutter lubrication and other claimed advantages, it has not been taken up to any significant extent by the Australian woolgrowing industry, possibly due to the additional cost of providing a satisfactory compressed air supply.

A manoeuvreable handpiece such as the Able Star is useful in conjunction with mechanical restraint shearing but as has been explained previously few woolgrowers or shearers appear to find this form of shearing attractive.

(11) By way of explanation, the purpose of the AWC in making recommendations for the use of the Wool Research Trust Fund in wool harvesting is to enable new ideas and initiatives to be investigated and to disseminate useful information to the Wool Growing Industry. It is not normal practice to recommend the application of the Fund in respect of innovations which have been developed to the stage where they can be commercially implemented.

In earlier years of the Wool Harvesting Program emphasis was given to the more obvious and easier potential solutions, many of them devised by woolgrowers themselves as well as other innovative individuals. It is not uncommon for an inventor to make over-optimistic assessments of the value of his invention and in many instances it was necessary to assist in the construction and testing of such innovations to determine their potential value to the industry as objectively as possible. To a certain extent therefore the AWC responded to a demand from the industry to test such new devices, largely in the area of mechanical restraint shearing and to assist in making the more promising of these devices known to the industry.

Thus the AWC, through its recommended use of the Wool Research Trust Fund and/or the provision of technical assistance, was associated in varying degrees with the testing of chain (or production-line) shearing in the 'six-cutter' and 'two-cutter' versions of the overhead track system, the 'Tunsey' belt chain system and many variations of 'one man-one sheep' restraint shearing, either involving the principles of upside-down restraint as used in overhead track chain shearing or shearing tables and cradles such as the Thomas-Wundenberg cradle (later manufactured as the 'Pederick' cradle) and the Clark cradle. Other devices embodying similar principles and developed at about the same time, but with less involvement of the AWC, are the McKinnon and Meclock Shearing Tables.
During the same period the AWC was associated with the development of the 'Derriere' sheep handler and, later, the Rotary Sheep Delivery Platform.

Some of these devices were constructed or purchased with grants from the Wool Research Trust Fund or borrowed to enable their display to the Wool Industry under working conditions at field-days throughout Australia.

Some of these new devices ultimately became commercially available but after initial interest from a minority of woolgrowers, that interest waned as it became evident that the devices did not provide an acceptable alternative method to conventional shearing.

Hence, many of these devices were developed by individual woolgrowers with the public sector being involved in testing, demonstrating and in some instances development to the stage where an objective evaluation could be made but not beyond that point to commercial production and sale, which is not a normal avenue for expenditure of a rural research trust fund.

Most of the developments which have proven of use to woolgrowers over the period from 1972-73 to 1979-80 have arisen in the activities associated with shearing rather than the actual shearing operation itself. Amongst such developments have been:
(i) better shed designs, in which public sector bodies such as the University of Melbourne and the State Departments of Agriculture have played a major role;

(ii) heavier shed bales, which reduce costs of packs, transport and warehousing, and which have been advocated by public sector bodies such as the National Materials Handling Bureau and the AWC for at least a decade. The development of presses to make such bales has occurred within the private sector as press manufacturers have responded to grower demands;

(iii) simpler wool preparation, such as the use of Objective Clip Preparation which reduces labour requirements in the shearing shed and largely arose from research undertaken by the University of NSW and the Bureau of Agricultural Economics in the late 1960's and subsequent activities by the AWC and CSIRO in the 1970's. (Further savings are likely in this area as a result of continuing research by the AWC and CSIRO into wool preparation procedures);

(iv) virtual elimination on piece picking, which has been materially assisted by AWC studies showing that many woolrollers/classers are unnecessarily skirting fleeces too heavily, thus leading to the loss of good fleece wool in skirtings or the need to employ a piece picker to separate out this fleece wool from the poorer skirtings.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Cricket Helmets: Exemption from Sales Tax

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 November 1980 (Hansard, page 107), Senator Young addressed to me as Minister representing the Treasurer in the Senate, a question without notice concerning the exemption from sales tax of safety helmets worn by cricketers. I undertook to refer the question to the Treasurer who has provided the following answer:

ANSWER.PARA: Following a similar question addressed by the honourable senator to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs in the Senate, I arranged for the question of exempting all sporting goods from sales tax to be considered during the preparation of the 1980-81 Budget. Cricket helmets are not the only safety items worn by participants in sporting activities that are subject to tax and it would have been discriminatory to single out helmets for individual consideration in the budgetary context. By the same token, it might have been seen as a partial approach if sporting safety equipment had been considered and not the basic playing equipment. That is why the budgetary consideration extended to the whole range of sporting equipment.

The view taken at that time was that the prospective budgetary situation was such as to preclude the introduction of this and other particular concessions that had been sought in both the sales tax and the income tax areas.

As for the distinction mentioned by the honourable senator between the sales tax treatment of cricket helmets and cyclists' helmets, playing gear is subject to tax but not clothing worn by players. The exemption for clothing does, however, specifically exclude protective headwear, protective pads, guards, gloves or mittens which are of a kind used exclusively or primarily and principally for the purposes of sport or recreation. Cricket helmets are clearly covered by the exclusion. On the other hand, most cyclists' helmets are used by persons who cycle for purposes other than sport or recreation (transport being the main use) and are not caught by the exclusion.

I add that, whether safety gear is exempt or not, it seems to me that prudence and self-interest would point strongly to the desirability of players wearing such gear. However that may be, where prudence and self-interest are insufficient persuaders, it is very doubtful that the modest reductions in retail price that might be expected from a sales tax exemption would prove sufficient in that regard.
